::''Not to be confused with the early Radical Zionist faction in Poland under the leadership of [[Yitzhak Gruenbaum]]''. {{Infobox Newspaper | name = Al HaMishmar | logo = | image = | caption = | type = Daily newspaper | format = | owners = [[Hashomer Hatzair]]
[[Mapam]] | publisher = | editor = | chiefeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = 30 July 1943 | political = [[Mapam]] | language = [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] | ceased publication = 31 March 1995 | headquarters = | circulation = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | website = | publishing_country = [[Mandatory Palestine|Mandate Palestine]]
[[Israel]] }} '''''Al HaMishmar''''' ({{lang-he-n|על המשמר}}, lit. ''On Guard'') was a daily newspaper published in [[Mandatory Palestine|Mandate Palestine]] and [[Israel]] between 1943 and 1995. The paper was owned by, and affiliated with [[Hashomer Hatzair]] as well as the [[Hashomer Hatzair Workers Party of Palestine]], which became [[Mapam]] after 1948. ==History== The paper was established under the name '''Mishmar''' on 30 July 1943 as the journal of Hashomer Hatzair. At the top of the first page of every issue was the banner "For Zionism, Socialism and Brotherhood amongst Nations". Its readership was mainly based on subscriptions from [[Kibbutz Artzi]], Hashomer Hatzair and Mapam members. The name Al HaMishmar first appeared on the edition of 25 January 1948. Its journalists included [[Yoel Marcus]], [[Eliezer Peri]], [[Tom Segev]], [[Shelly Yachimovich]] and [[Avi Benayahu]], whilst [[Leah Goldberg]], [[Avraham Shlonsky]], [[Yehoshua Sobol]] and [[Yitzhak Orpaz-Auerbach]] were all contributors. The paper also had an Arabic version, ''al-Mersad'', of which [[Abd el-Aziz el-Zoubi]] and [[Muhammed Wattad]] were amongst the editors. From 1993 Kibbutz Artzi members were no longer automatically subscribers, and in 1995 the paper was closed, with the last edition on 31 March.[http://tnuathaavoda.info/zope/home/100/press/1123404477/ Al HaMishmar] Tnua't HaAvoda {{he icon}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://web.nli.org.il/sites/JPress/English/Pages/al_hamishmar.aspx Complete archive of HaMishmar through 1955] [[Historical Jewish Press]] {{Newspapers in Israel}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Al HaMishmar}} [[Category:Publications established in 1943]] [[Category:Hebrew-language newspapers]] [[Category:Publications disestablished in 1995]] [[Category:Defunct newspapers of Israel]] [[Category:1943 establishments in Mandatory Palestine]] [[Category:1995 disestablishments in Israel]]

[[File:Altar2.jpg|thumb|250px|Altar completely wrapped in white altar cloths like in the [[Neocatechumenal Way]] celebration of the Eucharist ]] [[File:Divine Liturgy Preparations at Ukrainian Catholic Cathedral, London.jpg|thumb|250px|Altar topped with white altar cloth as in the [[Latin Church]] and this [[Byzantine Rite]] tradition]] An '''altar cloth''' is used by various religious groups to cover an [[altar]]. It may be used as a sign of respect towards the holiness of the altar, as in the [[Catholic Church]]. Because many altars are made of wood and are often ornate and unique, cloth may then be used to protect the altar surface. In other cases, the cloth serves to beautify a rather mundane construction underneath.
== Christian altar cloths ==
===Western Churches=== [[File:St-john-divine-high-altar.jpg|thumb|250px|The High Altar at [[St. John the Divine, Kennington]], London.]]
Special cloths (not necessarily made of [[linen]]) cover the [[altar]] in many [[Christian]] [[church (building)|church]]es during services and celebrations, and are often left on the altar when it is not in use. In the early 20th century the [[Roman Catholic Church]] considered only [[linen]] or [[hemp]] to be acceptable as material for altar cloths, although in earlier centuries silk or cloth of gold or silver were used.<ref name = CathEn>{{cite CE1913 |mode=cs2 |first=Augustin Joseph |last=Schulte |wstitle=Altar Cloths |display=Altar-Cloths |volume=1}}</ref> The [[Anglican Communion]] had similar rules in that period.<ref>{{Citation | last =Project Canterbury | contribution =Ritual Notes—Of the Altars and Other Sacred Ornaments | year =1894 | title =The Order of Divine Service | place=Oxford | publisher =Mowbray & Co. | url = http://anglicanhistory.org/liturgy/ritual_notes_1894/notes1.html | accessdate = 2006-07-07}}</ref>
At that time, the [[Roman Rite]] required the use of three altar cloths, to which a '''cere cloth''', not classified as an altar cloth, was generally added. This was a piece of heavy linen treated with [[wax]] (''cera'', from which "cere" is derived, is the [[Latin language|Latin]] word for "wax") to protect the altar linens from the dampness of a stone altar, and also to prevent the altar from being stained by any wine that may be spilled. It was exactly the same size as the ''mensa'' (the flat rectangular top of the altar).
Above this were placed two '''linen cloths'''. Like the cere cloth, they were made of heavy linen exactly the same size as the mensa of the altar. They acted as a cushion and, with the cere cloth, prevented the altar from being dented by heavy vases or communion vessels placed on top. Instead of two cloths, a single long cloth folded so that each half covered the whole mensa was acceptable.
The topmost cloth was the '''fair linen''', a long white linen cloth laid over the two linen cloths. It had the same depth as the mensa of the altar, but was longer, generally hanging over the edges to within a few inches of the floor or, according to some authorities, it should hang 18 inches over the ends of the mensa. On an altar without [[antependium]] and consisting of the mensa resting on columns or made after the fashion of a tomb the topmost linen did not have to overhang the edges at the sides. It could be trimmed with lace on the ends and could be ornamented with figures of chalices, hosts and the like. Five small crosses might be embroidered on the fair linen - one to fall at each corner of the mensa, and one in the middle of the front edge. These symbolised the five [[stigmata|wound]]s of Jesus. The fair linen should be left on the altar at all times. When removed for replacement, it should be rolled, not folded. It symbolized the [[shroud]] in which [[Jesus Christ|Jesus]] was wrapped for burial.
*A '''vesperal cloth''', or '''coverlet''', of the same heavy linen as the cere cloth and the linen cloths, and of the same length and width as the fair linen, was left on the altar whenever it is not in use. It simply protects the altar from dust and debris.
The present rules of the Roman Rite are much less detailed, stating only: {{Quote|Out of reverence for the celebration of the memorial of the Lord and for the banquet in which the Body and Blood of the Lord are offered, there should be, on an altar where this is celebrated, at least one cloth, white in colour, whose shape, size, and decoration are in keeping with the altar's structure.<ref>[http://www.liturgyoffice.org.uk/Resources/GIRM/Documents/GIRM.pdf General Instruction of the Roman Missal], 304</ref>}}
====Chalice cloths==== [[File:Purificatorium on chalice.JPG|thumb|250px|A purificator laid on a chalice]] [[File:Palla.JPG|thumb|A pall, embroidered with the ''[[Agnus Dei]]'']] [[File:Kelkvelum.jpg|thumb|200px|A [[chalice veil]] laid over the holy vessels]] [[File:Bursa used in church.jpg|thumb|A burse]] There are also special linens which pertain to the Eucharist:
*The '''[[purificator]]''' (''purificatorium'' or more anciently ''emunctorium'')<ref name = Chalice>{{cite CE1913 |mode=cs2 |last=Thurston |first=Herbert |wstitle=Chalice |volume=3}}</ref> is a white linen cloth which is used to wipe the [[chalice (cup)|chalice]] after each [[communicant]] partakes. It is also used to wipe the chalice and paten after the [[Ablution in Christianity|ablutions]] which follow Communion. *The '''pall''' (''palla'') is a stiffened square card covered with white linen, usually embroidered with a cross, or some other appropriate symbol. The purpose of the pall is to keep dust and insects from falling into the Eucharistic elements. *The '''[[corporal (liturgy)|corporal]]''' is a square white cloth upon which the chalice and [[paten]] are placed when the Eucharist is celebrated. It may be edged with fine lace, and a cross may be embroidered on it near the front edge, where the Tridentine Mass prescribed that the host be placed. Embroidery in the centre was not used, lest the chalice become unstable.<ref>{{Citation | last =De Herdt | first = | year =1894 | title =S. Liturgiæ praxis (9th ed.) | pages =I, n. 167 | place=Louvain}}</ref> *The '''[[manuterge]]''' (also called ''lavabo towel'') is used by the priest to dry his or her hands after washing them (see [[lavabo]]). *The '''[[chalice veil]]''': "It is a praiseworthy practice for the chalice to be covered with a veil, which may be either of the colour of the day or white."<ref>General Instruction of the Roman Missal, 118</ref> *In the [[Tridentine Mass]], the rubrics for [[Low Mass]] form obliged the priest to begin by carrying with him from the sacristy to the altar the chalice, upon which was placed the purificator, paten and pall, all of these covered with a chalice veil and surmounted by a '''[[burse]]''' (known in Old English as a "corporas-case")<ref name = Chalice/> containing the corporal. The burse was a folder made of two square pieces of cardboard laid one on top of the other and bound together along one edge to form a hinge. The two pieces were attached with cloth along the two sides adjacent to the hinge, leaving the fourth end open to receive the corporal.<ref>{{cite CE1913 |mode=cs2 |last=Peterson |first=John B. |wstitle=Burse |volume=3}}</ref> At the end of Mass, the priest carried all these back to the sacristy, arranged after the same fashion. The present General Instruction of the Roman Missal does not envisage the use of a burse.
====Frontals==== {{main|antependia}} In the Roman Catholic Church and the Anglican Communion all of the linen cloths are white, including their decoration. Other more decorative cloths sometimes used to decorate the front and back of the altar are:
*The '''frontal''', or [[Antependia|Antependium]], is the same size as the front of the altar. It is richly decorated, made of [[tapestry]], [[silk]] or [[damask]]. Some frontals are matchless works of art, exhibiting the finest materials and [[embroidery]] possible. Other churches opt for a plain frontal. One characteristic is shared by all frontals: they are coloured green, red, purple, blue, black, white, gold or of unbleached muslin, and are changed according to the colour of the Church year. Purple or blue for Advent; white or gold for Christmas, Easter and some Holy Days; green for Ordinary Time (after Epiphany and Pentecost); violet or purple or unbleached muslin for Lent; red for Holy Week, Pentecost and feasts of martyred saints (in some Anglican parishes there is a special crimson set for Holy Week). In this way the altar has various different frontals hung upon it throughout the year, but only one at a time. The frontal may be fixed to either the cere cloth or the linen cloth to hold it in place, which cloth must be fastened to the rear edge of the altar. *The '''frontlet''' is similar to the frontal, that is the exact width of the altar, but only ten to twelve inches deep. It hangs over the frontal, and is of the same colour and material. Again, the frontlet is rotated according to the colour of the church year. Like the frontal the frontlet is fastened to either the cere cloth or the linen cloth. Or, alternatively, it may be fastened to a wooden frame or strip that can be hooked in place at the front of the altar.
==== Variants ==== According to the ''[[Catholic Encyclopedia]]'', altar-cloths were commonly used prior to the 4th century. [[Pope Boniface III]] is reputed to have passed a decree in the 7th century making the use of altar cloths mandatory. The use of three cloths most likely began in the 9th century and was obligatory for Roman Catholic churches at the time of the Catholic Encyclopedia.<ref name = CathEn/><ref>{{Citation | title =Rubricae Generales Missalis Rom. | pages =tit. xx: ''De Defectibus'', tit. x, 1}}</ref>
Previously, all Christian Churches used altar cloths. However, today some use no cloths on the altar or only the fair linen. Several variants of the above cloths and linens are also in use. Some Churches use a frontlet and no frontal, especially where the altar is richly decorated and a frontal would hide it. Where only a frontlet is used, in many cases the frontlet is permanently attached to the linen cloth, and so the linen cloth must be replaced with the frontlet. Many Churches dispense with the cere cloth and the coverlet.
Many churches of the Anglican Communion follow the tradition of the [[Latin Church]] in preparing the altar for the Eucharist. There are varying practices in the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]]; some do not use the elaborate altar dressing previously laid down for the Roman Catholic Church and usually use only a white ''fair linen'' cloth to cover the top of the altar. According to a glossary found on an Episcopal parish's website, the altar cloth they use "... covers the top of the altar and hangs down the sides almost to the floor."<ref>{{Citation | last =Trinity Episcopal Church | contribution =Altar Cloth | title =Glossary | place =North Scituate, R.I. | url =http://www.trinityepiscopalonline.org/glossary-a.htm | accessdate =2006-07-18 | format =– <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3ATrinity+Episcopal+Church+intitle%3AGlossary&as_publication=&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup> | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20060810230011/http://www.trinityepiscopalonline.org/glossary-a.htm | archivedate =2006-08-10 | df = }} </ref> [[Lutheran]]s also use a single ''fair linen'' on their altar, though many use the coloured frontlet or frontal as well.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lcms.org/pages/internal.asp?NavID=714 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091222014039/http://www.lcms.org/pages/internal.asp?NavID=714 |archivedate=2009-12-22 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last =St. Paul Lutheran Church= | contribution =Altar Guild | title =Activities | place =Melbourne, FL | url =http://www.stpaulmelb.com/altarguild.html | accessdate =2006-07-18 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070520020144/http://www.stpaulmelb.com/altarguild.html | archivedate =2007-05-20 | df = }}</ref>
Likewise, ''The Doctrines and Discipline of the Methodist Church'' specifies that "The Lord's Table should have upon it a fair linen cloth."<ref>{{cite book|title=The Doctrines and Discipline of the Methodist Church|year=1960|publisher=The Methodist Publishing House|location=Nashville, Tennessee |language=English|page=522}}</ref>
===Eastern Churches=== [[File:Liturgia.jpg|thumb|250px|A [[Russian Orthodox]] priest celebrating [[Divine Liturgy]]. On the [[Holy Table]] (altar) is a green ''indítia'', and the ''[[Antimens]]'' (gold) with its ''eileton'' (red) has been opened.]]
In the [[Eastern Orthodox]] and [[Eastern Catholic]] Churches of Byzantine Rite, the altar is referred to as the Holy Table or Throne ([[Church Slavonic]]: ''Prestol''). Although there are variations, normally it will be completely covered on all four sides with three clothes.
*The '''Strachítsa''' is the first cloth to cover the Holy Table. It is a plain [[linen]] cover which is bound to the altar with cords at the time of its [[consecration]], and is never removed. This linen covering symbolizes the [[Epitaphios (liturgical)|winding sheet]] in which the [[body of Christ]] was wrapped when he was laid in the [[Holy Sepulchre|tomb]]. Since the altar is never seen uncovered thereafter, these tend to be constructed more with sturdiness than aesthetics in mind. *The '''Indítia''' is placed above this first cover and is an ornamented cover, often in a brocade of a color that may change with the [[liturgical year|liturgical season]]. This outer covering usually comes all the way to the floor and represents the glory of God's Throne.<ref name=Hapgood>Isabel Hapgood. ''Service Book of the Holy Orthodox-Catholic Apostolic Church'' (Antiochian Orthodox Christian Archdiocese, 1975), p. xxix.</ref> When the ''Indítia'' is laid out flat it forms a [[Greek cross]], with the center covering the top of the Holy Table, and the "arms" of the cross covering the four sides.<ref name=Hapgood/> *A third covering is made of the same material as the Indítia, but is smaller and square, covering the top of the Holy Table and coming down only a few inches on all four sides, something like the Western frontlet.
The '''[[Antimension]]''' ([[Church Slavonic]]: ''Antimens'') is similar to the Western corporal, though it serves a function similar to an [[altar stone]]. It is a piece of silk or linen which has an [[icon]] of the [[Deposition from the Cross]] depicted on it, and [[relic]]s of a [[martyr]] sewn into it. Unlike the Western corporal, the Antimension is not removed from the Holy Table after the Eucharist is over, but is kept in the center of the Holy Table, covered by the [[Gospel Book]].
The Antimension is wrapped in a slightly larger cloth, called the '''Eiliton''' to protect it. The Eiliton is often red.
[[File:Aer on a Chalice and Discos.jpg|thumb|left|300px|The [[diskos]] and [[chalice (cup)|chalice]] covered by the [[Aër]] at the conclusion of the [[Proskomedie]].]]
The Eastern chalice veil is called the '''[[Aër]]''' and is quite a bit larger than the chalice veil used in the West. In addition to the Aër, there are two other smaller veils. These are often cross-shaped like the Indítia and one is used to cover the chalice, and one is used to cover the ''[[diskos]]'' (paten).
There are usually one or two '''communion cloths''' ([[housel]]ling cloths) kept on the Holy Table. These are made of cotton or some similar material that can be easily washed and are often dyed red. They are used like the Western purificator to wipe the lips of the communicants and to dry the chalice and other sacred vessels after the ablutions.
A dust cover is frequently used, either to cover only the [[Gospel Book]] or the entire top of the Holy Table. This cover is not, strictly speaking, a liturgical object, but is purely utilitarian. Because it will rest upon the Holy Table, it is usually made of a fair material, but not normally as rich as the ''inditia''.
Towels are used to dry the hands after [[lavabo]], though their design and use are not as fixed as formerly in the West. When a bishop washes his hands, a larger and more ornate towel is used to dry his hands.
== Judaism == According to the Bible the Jews were using altar ''cloths'' at the time of the Exodus, "...And the table and his furniture, and the pure candlestick with all his furniture, and the altar of incense ... and the altar of burnt offering with all his furniture, and the laver and his foot, and the cloths of service..." ({{bibleverse||Exodus|31:8-10|HE}})<!--The translation "cloths of service" of the KJV, in the Hebrew is "plaited garments" and refers to the garments of the priests, rather than any coverings for the altar(s).-->
The Jews traditionally used colour, "And of the blue, and purple, and scarlet, they made cloths of service..." which were to be used by the priests inside the tabernacle. Since all of the other items made from fabric for use in the tabernacle were made from fine linen it is reasonable to assume that the ''cloths of service'' were also made from linen.({{bibleverse||Exodus|39:1|HE}}) Unfortunately, Exodus does not give the dimensions of the cloths, nor does it indicate how or when the cloths were to be used.
The practice of using altar cloths disappeared when the [[Temple in Jerusalem]] was destroyed in AD 70. The focus of worship turned towards the [[synagogue]] and the need for an altar disappeared. There is a table where the Torah scrolls are laid for reading, called a ''[[Bema#Judaism|bimah]]'', and another lower table called an ''amud'', that is, a lectern. The lectern is covered with an embroidered cloth covering the area on which the [[Torah scroll]] will rest during the ''[[parashah]]'' ([[lection]]—see [[Torah reading]]). The [[Torah ark]] in the synagogue is covered with a cloth called the ''[[parokhet]]'' to recall the veil which covered the entrance to the [[Holy of Holies]].
== See also == *[[Veil]] *[[Antimension]] * [[Shroud of Turin]], possible cloth that covered Jesus, as inspiration of nearly all Christian altar cloths

{{Bahá'í sidebar}} The [[Bahá'í Faith]] in [[Italy]] dates from 1899 - the earliest known date for Bahá'ís in Italy.{{Cite magazine| title = Report form Italy|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1930 | number = 43 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =8 | url =}} Bahá'í sources currently claim about 3,000 adherents in Italy in over 300 locations. The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying mostly on projections from the [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated some 5000 Bahá'ís in Italy in 2005.{{Cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp| accessdate = 2010-01-30}} [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], head of the religion from 1892 to 1921, wrote two letters to Italian Bahá'ís and mentioned Italy a few times addressing issues of war and peace as well.{{Cite book| last = Abbas | first = `Abdu'l-Bahá |others=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab (trans. and comments) | title = Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation |date=April 1919 | url =http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}} Though several people joined the religion before [[World War II]] by the end there may have been just one Bahá'í in the country.{{Cite magazine| title = News From Other Lands; Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1946 | number = 10 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=18–20 | url =}} Soon a wave of [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] was coordinated{{Cite book| last = Mooman | first = Moojan | editor = Peter Smith | title = Bahá'ís in the West | publisher = Kalimat Press | year = 2004 | pages = 63–109 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=x7wyJdyE60oC&pg=PA88&vq=german&source=gbs_search_s&sig=ACfU3U3qKat232TFk1eGQpo523IUJX_G0Q | isbn = 1-890688-11-8 }} with the first Bahá'ís to arrive were Angeline and [[Ugo Giachery]].{{Cite book| authors = Universal House of Justice | title = In Memoriam | journal = The Bahá'í World | volume = XVIII | publisher = Bahá'í World Centre | pages = 717–719 | year = 1986 | url =http://bahai-library.com/books/bw18/693-719.html | isbn = 0-85398-234-1 | others = prepared under the supervision of the Universal House of Justice.}}{{Cite magazine| title = Four More Pioneers Leave for Europe |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1947 | number = 192 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =1 | url =}} By [[Ridván]] 1948 the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] of Rome was elected.{{Cite magazine| title = Europeau Enrollments Increase |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1948 | number = 205 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =9 | url =}} There were six communities across Italy and Switzerland when a regional national assembly was formed in 1953.{{Cite magazine| title = First Annual Convention Bahá'ís of Italy and Switzerland |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1953 | number = 266 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =2 | url =}} The Italian Bahá'ís elected their own [[National Spiritual Assembly]] in 1962.{{Cite web| last = Hassall | first = Graham | title = Notes on Research on National Spiritual Assemblies | work = Research notes | publisher = Asia Pacific Bahá'í Studies | url =http://bahai-library.com/hassall_nsas_years_formation | doi =| accessdate = 2010-02-21}} A survey of the community in 1963 showed 14 assemblies and 18 smaller communities.{{Cite web| url =http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1#19 | title = The Bahá'í Faith: 1844-1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953-1963| author = Compiled by [[Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land | pages = 93–94, 111, 112}} Major conferences held in Italy include the Palermo Conference of 1968 to commemorate from the movement of [[Bahá'u'lláh]], the founder of the religion, from Gallipoli to the prison in [[Acre, Israel#Conservation projects|Acre]]{{Cite magazine| title = From Ciallipoli to the Most Great Prison; Message from the Universal House of Justice to Palermo |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1968 | number = 451 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=1–2| url =}} and the 2009 regional conference for southern Europe in Padua about the progress of the religion.{{Cite news| title = The Padua Regional Conference | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | location = Padua, Italy | language = | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | date = 7–8 February 2009 | url = http://news.bahai.org/community-news/regional-conferences/padua.html | accessdate = 2010-03-02}} == Early phase == Just before the founding of modern Italy [[Bahá'u'lláh]] addressed a message to [[Pope Pius IX]] a few years before the [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)#Unification process (1848–1870)|unification of the Kingdom of Italy]].{{Cite magazine| title = The Promised Day is Come by Shoghi Effendi - BOOK REVIEW |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1967 | number = 431 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=5–6 | url =}} It was part of the series entitled [[Summons of the Lord of Hosts#Súriy-i-Haykal (Tablet of the Temple)|Súriy-i-Haykal or Tablet of the Temple]] which was collected in English as part of the ''Summons of the Lord of Hosts''. As early as 1899 there were two Bahá'ís in Italy - Edith Burr in [[Florence]] and Maria Forni.{{Cite book|author=Cameron, G. |author2=Momen, W. |year= 1996 |title= A Basic Bahá'í Chronology |publisher= George Ronald |location=Oxford, UK |isbn= 0-85398-404-2 |pages = 146, 221, 260, 294, 355, 466 }} Burr was an American and a book of her poetry was published.{{Cite book| last = Burr | first = Edith |author2=trans. Nora Vittori | title = Italia; poesie di Edith Burr | publisher = Tip. Domenicana | location = Florence | url = http://opac.sbn.it/opacsbn/opaclib?db=iccu&select_db=iccu&nentries=1&from=13&searchForm=opac/iccu/error.jsp&resultForward=opac/iccu/full.jsp&do=search_show_cmd&rpnlabel=+Classificazione+Dewey+%3D+811.52+&rpnquery=%40attrset+bib-1++%40attr+1%3D13+%40attr+4%3D1+%22811.52%22&totalResult=263&ricerca=navigazione&fname=none&brief=brief| isbn = }} Forni was of Polish extraction, lived in [[Ticino]] initially where she ran a private school for children with disabilities and presented Bahá'í teachings{{Cite web|title=Introduction |work=Religioni del FODINT |publisher=Religion and Society Today and Tomorrow Living dialogue (FODINT) |date=2 September 2008 |url=http://fodint.kands-group.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=46:introduzione&catid=38:bahai&Itemid=67 |accessdate=2010-02-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713134323/http://fodint.kands-group.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=46%3Aintroduzione&catid=38%3Abahai&Itemid=67 |archivedate=2011-07-13 |df= }} but soon she moved to Crevenna near [[Lake Como]]. Both had died by 1930. Burr was the recipient of two letters from `Abdu'l-Bahá.{{Cite magazine| title = The First Italo-Swiss Convention-Florence, Italy|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1953 | number = 268 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=7–10 | url =}} It was in November 1900 that [[Agnes Alexander]] learned of the religion while visiting family in Rome. While there she met Charlotte Dixon, an American Bahá'í who was just returning from a [[Bahá'í pilgrimage]].{{Cite web| last = Troxel | first = Duane | title = Life of Agnes Alexander | work = Essays and Internet Postings | publisher = Bahá'í Internet Library | url = http://bahai-library.com/troxel_life_agnes_alexander | accessdate = 2010-02-21}}[ === Links with `Abdu'l-Bahá === [[Juliet Thompson]], a prominent early Bahá'í from the United States, went through Italy in 1909 on [[Bahá'í pilgrimage]] to meet `Abdu'l-Bahá.{{Cite book| last = Thompson | first = Juliet |author2=Marzieh Gail | title = The diary of Juliet Thompson | publisher = Kalimat Press | year = 1983 | location = |page=396 | url =http://bahai-library.com/books/thompson/2.html | isbn = 978-0-933770-27-0}} Another, [[Horace Holley (Bahá'í)|Horace Holley]] had set out for Europe in 1909 and met Bertha Herbert during the voyage. Herbert loaned him Myron Phelps' book about `Abdu'l-Bahá and Holley soon joined the religion. Herbert and Holley were married in October 1909 and settled in Italy. They then met `Abdu'l-Baha on both of his trips to Europe, and lived in Italy until 1912, when they moved to Paris.{{Cite web| last = Armstrong-Ingram | first = R. Jackson | title = Holley, Horace Hotchkiss | work = Biographies | publisher = Bahá'í Online Library | date = 2003-10-02 | url = http://bahai-library.com/armstrong-ingram_encyclopedia_horace_holley | accessdate = 2010-02-21}} Maria Forni was among those who visited `Abdu'l-Bahá when he arrived in Switzerland in 1911 on his first trip to the West. On his second trip `Abdu'l-Bahá and his retinue boarded the [[RMS Cedric]] in [[Alexandria, Egypt]] bound for [[Naples]] where they arrived on March 28, 1912 though they did not disembark for fear of being confused with Turks during the ongoing [[Italo-Turkish War]].{{Cite book|author = Zarqáni, Mírzá Mahmúd-i- |origyear = 1913 |year = 1998 |title = Mahmúd's Diary: Chronicling `Abdu'l-Bahá's Journey to America |publisher = George Ronald |location = Oxford, UK |isbn = 0-85398-418-2 |url =http://bahai-library.com/zarqani_mahmuds_diary }} Several Bahá'ís from America and Britain boarded the ship to travel with them. A youthful [[Shoghi Effendi]] had accompanied `Abdu'l-Bahá from Egypt but was refused further passage by reason of a minor illness and was taken ashore, though all were not convinced of the sincerity of the diagnosis and some presumed it was ill will against the voyagers as if they were Turkish. The American Bahá'ís had sent thousands of dollars for the journey, urging `Abdu'l-Bahá to leave the Cedric in Italy and travel to England to sail on the maiden voyage of the [[RMS Titanic]]. Instead he returned the money for charity and continued the voyage on the Cedric.{{Cite book| last = Lacroix-Hopson | first = Eliane |author2='Abdu'l-Bahá | title = 'Abdu'l-Bahá in New York - The City of the Covenant | publisher = NewVistaDesign | year = 1987 | pages = Introduction | url = http://bahai-library.com/hopson_abdulbaha_new_york | isbn = }} Later a survivor met with him asking why he didn't go on the Titanic and he suggested "God inspires man's heart."{{Cite book|author = Zarqáni, Mírzá Mahmúd-i- |origyear = 1913 |year = 1998 |page=218 |title = Mahmúd's Diary: Chronicling `Abdu'l-Bahá's Journey to America |publisher = George Ronald |location = Oxford, UK |isbn = 0-85398-418-2 |url =http://bahai-library.com/zarqani_mahmuds_diary }} Later in April 1912 `Abdu'l-Bahá is recorded addressing that war:
What a great tribulation there is in the countries of Italy and Turkey in these days! The fathers hear of the death of their sons and the sons are distressed on hearing the news of the death of their fathers. What cities are laid to ruin and what rising fortunes are thrown to the winds! The antidote for this great ill is world peace, which is the source of universal tranquillity.
While in the United States `Abdu'l-Bahá had dedicated the site of the North American [[Bahá'í House of Worship]]. By 1915 Italian Bahá'ís were among those contributing to its construction.{{Cite magazine| title = 'Abdu'l-Baha in America - 'The Temple is already built'; Note 6 |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1987 | number = 673 | ISSN= 0043-8804| page =8 | url =}} After his return to Egypt `Abdu'l-Bahá again took up mention of Italy and war. He wrote a series of letters, or [[tablets (religious)|tablets]], to the followers of the religion in the [[United States]] in 1916-1917; these letters were compiled together in the book ''[[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]''. The seventh of the tablets mentioned [[Europe]]an regions and was written on April 11, 1916, but was delayed in being presented in the United States until 1919—after the end of the [[World War I|First World War]] and the [[Spanish flu]]. The seventh tablet was translated and presented on April 4, 1919, and published in ''[[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West]]'' magazine on December 12, 1919 and mentioned Italy. He says:
"In brief, this world-consuming war has set such a conflagration to the hearts that no word can describe it. In all the countries of the world the longing for universal peace is taking possession of the consciousness of men. There is not a soul who does not yearn for concord and peace. A most wonderful state of receptivity is being realized.… Therefore, O ye believers of God! Show ye an effort and after this war spread ye the synopsis of the divine teachings in the British Isles, France, Germany, Austria-Hungary, Russia, Italy, Spain, Belgium, Switzerland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Holland, Portugal, Rumania, Serbia, Montenegro, Bulgaria, Greece, Andorra, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Monaco, San Marino, Balearic Isles, Corsica, Sardinia, Sicily, Crete, Malta, Iceland, Faroe Islands, Shetland Islands, Hebrides and Orkney Islands."{{Cite book|author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |origyear = 1916-17 |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-6.html | page = 43}}
=== Developments after World War I === Well known early Japanese Bahá'í [[Saichiro Fujita]] took a steamer to Italy about 1919-20, where he awaited `Abdu'l-Bahá's wire for him to proceed to Haifa.{{Cite magazine| title = Fujita-San |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1971 | number = 483 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =5 | url =}} There was communication noted with Bahá'ís in Italy in 1923.{{Cite web| last = Bahá'u'lláh | authorlink = Bahá'u'lláh | last2 = `Abdu'l-Bahá | last3 = Effendi | first3 = Shoghi| title = Baha'i Meetings | work = | publisher = | url =http://bahai-library.com/compilation_bahai_meetings| accessdate = 2010-02-21}} Imogene Hoagg was noted as present in Florence in 1925.{{Cite magazine| title = Foreign Bahá'í News|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1925 | number = 06 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=7–8 | url =}} Marion Jack sailed for Italy during January, 1926.{{Cite magazine| title = News of the Cause |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1926 | number = 10 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =5 | url =}} Anne Lynch fled Russia at the end of the first World War to settle in England and she accepted the Bahá'í Faith immediately upon first hearing of it in Italy in 1926 and then settled in Switzerland.{{Cite magazine| title = Memorial Services Honor Mrs. Anne Lynch |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1967 | number = 42 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =2 | url =}} A 1925 list of "leading local Bahá'í Centres" of Europe listed one in Italy.{{Cite news| last = Hassall | first = Graham | last2 = Fazel | first2 = Seena | title = 100 Years of the Bahá'í Faith in Europe | periodical = Bahá’í Studies Review | issue = 8 | pages = 35–44 | volume = 1998 | url =http://bahai-library.com/hassall_fazel_100-years_europe }} In 1930 a Bahá'í from Baghdad, a Mr. Toeg, was said to have moved to Milan.{{Cite magazine| title = Letter from the International Baha'i Bureau |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1930 | number = 42 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=6–8 | url =}} The first formal vote of international sanctions against aggression, taken in 1936 by the [[League of Nations]], when [[Italian Fascism|Fascist Italy]] invaded Ethiopia causing the [[Second Italo-Abyssinian War]], was hailed by [[Shoghi Effendi]], head of the religion from 1921 to 1957, as: "an event without parallel in human history".{{Cite book|first=Shoghi |last=Effendi |authorlink= Shoghi Effendi |year= 1938 |title= The World Order of Bahá’u’lláh |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn= 0-87743-231-7 |page = 191 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/WOB/index.html }} On May 25, 1940 Shoghi Effendi and [[Rúhíyyih Khanum]] obtained passports for Britain while in Rome - a few days later Italy entered [[World War II]]. === Redevelopment after World War II === Geresina Campani of Florence may have been the only Bahá'í to remain alive and active through World War II. Starting in 1946 Shoghi Effendi drew up plans for the American Bahá'í community to send [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] to Europe; the pioneers set up a European Teaching Committee chaired by [[Edna True]]. Possibly the first Bahá'ís after WWII to enter Italy were Angeline and [[Ugo Giachery]]. They reached Naples on 20 February 1947 and sent a telegram to Shoghi Effendi from Rome. By the end of March the first Italian convert was enrolled in Genoa. He was Augnsto Salvetti who heard of the religion from a Persian believer while he was a prisoner of war in India and investigated the religion on return to Italy.{{Cite magazine| title = First European Believer Under the Seven Year Plan|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1947 | number = 195 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =1 | url =}} Brother Rodolfo Salvetti soon followed joining the religion - and pioneers Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Marengella arrived in Italy by mid-1947.{{Cite magazine| title = The first two native Italian believers…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1947 | number = 196 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =1 | url =}} There was also one Bahá'í in Milan - perhaps a Turkish refugee.{{Cite magazine| title = European Survey; Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1947 | number = 194 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =9 | url =}} By early 1948 two more Italians had joined the religion - Verena Venturini{{Cite magazine| title = News From other Lands; Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1947 | number = 200 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =10 | url =}} and Luigi Peveri. By [[Ridván]] 1948 the first [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] of Rome was elected. In 1948, Marion Little pioneered to Florence from America.{{Cite magazine| title = Maud Bosio, a distinguished maidservant–An account of service rendered to the Cause in Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1974 | number = 521 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=18–20 | url =}} Well known Bahá'í [[Dorothy Beecher Baker]] who was later named as a [[Hand of the Cause]] undertook a trip from 1948 across Europe including visiting Italy.{{Cite magazine| title = Dorothy Baker - Golden years of a life of service to Cause |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1983 | number = 623 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=6–11 | url =}} Publications in Italian began with an introductory pamphlet which was sent to prominent citizens and to four hundred public libraries. This was followed by a new edition of [[John Esslemont]]'s ''Bahá`u'lláh and the New Era'', a special copy of which, bound in tooled green leather, was sent to the archives of the Bahá'í Faith in Palestine. Until 1964 when she returned to America, she served as chairman of the Italian Publishing Committee, a field which gave scope to her artistic and administrative skills. Under her direction and guidance many of the major Writings of the Faith were translated into Italian and published. She died in 1980 and her body buried in Cap d'Ail Cemetery, near [[Monaco]]. [[William Sutherland Maxwell]] came to Italy to begin reviewing materials for the expansion of the [[Shrine of the Bab]] in 1948{{Cite magazine| title = Shrine of the Báb Progresses |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1949 | number = 521 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=2–4 | url =}} which continued through 1951 with shipments to Palestine for the project.{{Cite book|first=Shoghi |last=Effendi |authorlink=Shoghi Effendi |year=1971 |title=Messages to the Bahá'í World, 1950-1957 |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=0-87743-036-5 |url= http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/MBW/mbw-77.html.utf8#gr1 | pages = 169–170 }} Architect Andrea Rocca, Professor Emeritus of the Beaux Arts Academy of Carrara, assisted in work with the Shrine as well as the later International Archives building.{{Cite magazine| title = International Baha'i Archives |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1956 | number = 303 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =7 | url =}} The first all-Bahá'í Italian family came to be in April 1949{{Cite magazine| title = New Believers in European Goal Countries |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1949 | number = 218 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =1 | url =}} followed by the conversion of 81-year-old Giuseppe Berardi by July.{{Cite magazine| title = Commander Giuseppe Berardi… |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1949 | number = 221 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =3 | url =}} == Growth of the religion == === Leading up to the election of the Regional Assembly === The early 1950s was a big period for development of the religion in Italy. The local assemblies of Florence and Naples were elected first in 1951.{{Cite magazine| title = European Teaching News|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1951 | number = 244 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =10 | url =}} Orientalist Alessandro Bausani joined the religion before April 1951{{Cite magazine| title = World Congress for World Federation|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1951 | number = 245 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =11 | url =}} - eventually he was Professor Emeritus and Director of the School of Oriental Studies and the Institute of Islamic Studies at the University of Rome "La Sapienza", and he was a member of the "Lincei" National Academy.{{Cite web| title = Alessandro Bausani | work = Special Collections | publisher = International Bahá'í Library | url = http://library.bahai.org/sc/bau1.html | accessdate = 2010-03-06}} He helped sustain every institution or committee, national or local, on which he was called to serve. Emily Maude Waterworth Bosio ("Maud Bosio") was 54 years of age when she joined the religion in January 1953. During her fifteen years of service, Bosio was usually a member of the assembly of Florence. And the Bahá'í community in Sicily began in 1953.{{Cite magazine| title = First Sicilian Community Contributes New Translations|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1958 | number = 330 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =19 | url =}} ==== First Italo-Swiss Convention ==== There were six communities across Italy and Switzerland who elected 19 delegates who gathered for the convention to elect a regional national assembly in the city of [[Florence]][http://bahai-library.com/compilation_germany_francy_italy Germany, France, Italy, and Switzerland] A Compilation of Bahá'í Writings Prepared by the Research Department of the Universal House of Justice in the presence of [[Hand of the Cause]] [[Paul E. Haney]] and Ugo Giachary and Edna True, Chairman of the European Teaching Committee and who represented the National Spiritual Assembly of the United States at the proceedings. The proceedings included announcements of letters of `Abdu'l-Bahá to Italians, noted the attendance of 18 of the 19 delegates, elected the officers of the convention, welcomed guests, discussed the progress of the religion in the region, the role of the Bahá'í institutions, celebrated the [[Ridván]] events, and the actual secret ballot election of the national assembly. Its first members were: Dr. Ugo Giachery, Friedrich Schar, Dr. Alessandro Bausani, Marion Little, Prof. Mario Fiorentini, Anna Kunz, Stella Lanzar, Anne Lynch, and Elsa Steinmetz. Letters from the eleven other national assemblies then in existence were shared and there was an announcement that these assemblies were welcomed to a continental conference in Sweden later in the same year. Workshops at the convention were held on [[Bahá'í administration]] and tributes paid to various firsts in the community. A public session was then held at which Ugo Giachery spoke on the theme of a universal fermentation giving rise to civilization. Alessandro Bausani was a member of this regional assembly during all the years of its existence.{{Cite web| title = Alessandro Bausani | work = Special Collections | publisher = International Bahá'í Library | url =http://library.bahai.org/sc/bau3.html |page = 3 | accessdate = 2010-03-06}} === Leading up to the election of the National Assembly === In October 1953 Marie Ciocca moved to [[Cagliari]] in Sardinia and was appointed by Shoghi Effendi as a [[Knight of Bahá'u'lláh]].{{Cite journal| author = Universal House of Justice | authorlink = Universal House of Justice | title = In Memoriam | journal = The Bahá'í World | volume = XV | publisher = Bahá'í World Centre | pages = 437–438 | year = 1976 |url = | isbn = | others = prepared under the supervision of the Universal House of Justice.}} In January 1954 it was announced Hand of the Cause [[Dorothy Beecher Baker]] had died in a plane crash near the island of Elba en route to Rome from [[Bahá'í Faith in Pakistan|Pakistan]] where she had toured after helping an international conference in [[Bahá'í Faith in India|India]].{{Cite magazine| title = Dorothy Baker - A personal reminiscence |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1977 | number = 276 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=8–9 | url =}} In February that all the goals assigned to Italy and Switzerland had all been settled by pioneers: [[Liechtenstein]], [[Monaco]], [[San Marino]], and the islands of [[Sicily]], [[Sardinia]] and [[Rhodes]].{{Cite magazine| title = Goals for Italy and Switzerland Settled|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1954 | number = 276 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =3 | url =}} In September Italy and Switzerland held its first summer school - 75 Bahá'ís attended the classes held in [[Bex les Bains]].{{Cite magazine| title = International News; Italy-Switzerland|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1954 | number = 286 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =4 | url =}} Following the work on the Shrine of the Báb further contracts were signed for materials and work for the [[Bahá'í World Centre buildings#International Archives|International Archives building]].{{Cite magazine| title = International News; Italy-Switzerland|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1955 | number = 292 | ISSN=0195-9212 | pages = 2–3 | url =}} The 3rd convention of the election of the Italo-Swiss assembly noted local assemblies had been elected in the goal location of [[Monte Carlo]], Monaco.{{Cite magazine| title = Italo-Switzerland; Third Italo-Swiss Convention |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1955 | number = 292 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =10 | url =}} On 9 May 1955, following disruption of the Bahá'í community of Tehran Iran, the Shah's personal physician, [[Abdol Karim Ayadi]], a Bahá'í, was told to leave the country for a while. For this reason he went to Italy for about nine months.{{Cite newsgroup | title = Falfsafi & the Bahá'ís of Iran | author = A.W. Samii | date = 1996-01-15 | newsgroup = soc.culture.iranian |message-id= 4df8kh$iag@newsbf02.news.aol.com| url = http://bahai-library.com/samii_kashani_bahais | accessdate = 2010-03-06}} Rita van Sombeek had been living in the Netherlands from 1947 but moved to Italy in the early 1950s where she served the interests of the religion.[http://bahai-library.com/hoonaard_encyclopedia_netherlands A Short Encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith] A Project of the National Spiritual Assembly of the U.S., by Will C. van den Hoonaard, 8 November 1993 In 1955 the national center building of the Bahá'ís of Italy was dedicated in Rome.{{Cite magazine| title = Group at the dedication of the Haziratu'l-Quds of Rome…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1956 | number = 299 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =4 | url =}} After causing [[Bahá'í divisions]] in 1957, [[Charles Mason Remey]], took up residence in Florence where he died in April 1974.Johns Hopkins University Library Special Collections. See 'Biographical Note'[https://web.archive.org/web/20051024055044/http://www.library.jhu.edu/collections/specialcollections/manuscripts/msregisters/ms375.html]. Retrieved September 7, 2008. The local assembly of [[Palermo]] was first elected in 1958. The first spiritual assemblies of [[Genova]]{{Cite magazine| title = Group at the dedication of the Haziratu'l-Quds of Rome…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1959 | number = 341 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =23 | url =}} and [[Milano]]{{Cite magazine| title = Local Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of Milano…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1959 | number = 342 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =16 | url =}} were elected in 1959. By 1959 Italian Julio Savi was an active Bahá'í doing work in [[Ethiopia]].{{Cite magazine| title = Church Attack on Asmara Summer School - Followed by Declarations of New Believers|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1959 | number = 346 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=6–7 | url =}} Italian Augusto Robiati also became a Bahá'í in Ethiopia and Savi and Robiati later returned to Italy.{{Cite web| title = Augusto Robiati | work = | publisher = Augusto Robiati| url =http://www.augustorobiati.it/savi.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2010-02-20}} In years to come Robiati would win peace and literary prizes.{{Cite magazine| title = Around the World; Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1985 | number = 650 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =14 | url =}} In 1959 Italian materials, after being part of the Shrine of the Báb and the building of the International Archives, began to be incorporated into the [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] in Kampala.{{Cite magazine| title = Main Structure of Kampala Temple Completed |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1959 | number = 346 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =5 | url =}} The first local assemblies of [[Venice]], [[Turin]],{{Cite magazine| title = Local Assemblies formed in the Baha'i World|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1960 | number = 353 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=17, 19 | url =}} and [[Perugia]]{{Cite magazine| title = Local Assemblies formed Ridvan 1960|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1961 | number = 359 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =12 | url =}} were all elected in 1960 (the first Baha'i arrived in Perugia in 1959.{{Cite magazine| title = Around the World; Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1986 | number = 661 | ISSN= 0043-8804| page =16 | url =}}) Bahá'ís with a background or interest in pioneering gathered in Rome in November 1960 and discussed goals remaining in the country in three languages as well as holding classes on the subjects of the Universal House of Justice and "Catholic Psychology and Bahá'í Faith" and other topics.{{Cite magazine| title = Pioneers Meet With Italian Believers To Discuss Crusade Goals |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1961 | number = 360 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =7 | url =}} Hand of the Cause [[Enoch Olinga]] visited many places including Sicily and mainland Italy in 1960 and again in 1971. Julio Savi was a member of the local assembly of [[Bologna]] which first formed April 1961{{Cite magazine| title = New National and Local Assemblies Typify Growth of Faith|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1961 | number = 367 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =6 | url =}} while the first [[Trieste]],{{Cite magazine| title = Local Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of Trieste… |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1961 | number = 364 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =9 | url =}} [[Padua]], and [[Bari]]{{Cite magazine| title = New National and Local Assemblies Typify Growth of Faith |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1961 | number = 367 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=6–7 | url =}} assemblies also formed. Hand of the Cause Shu'á'u'lláh 'Alá'i visited the Bahá'ís of Milan in 1961.{{Cite magazine| title = Hand of the Cause Shu'á'u'lláh 'Alá'i visits… |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1962 | number = 370 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =15 | url =}} In early 1962 Hand of the Cause [[`Alí-Akbar Furútan]] visited Bahá'ís in Florence{{Cite magazine| title = Hand of the Cause of God `Alí-Akbar Furútan… |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1962 | number = 373 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =11 | url =}} and Milan.{{Cite magazine| title = Hand of the Cause of God `Alí-Akbar Furútan… |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1962 | number = 375 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =12 | url =}} The 1962 edition of the ''Italian Books and Periodicals'', a review of Italian language publications by the government listed ''Le lezioni di San Giovanni d'Acri'' which was an independent translation of [[Some Answered Questions]].{{Cite magazine| title = Baha'i in the News|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1962 | number = 376 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =22 | url =}} ==== Public meetings ==== Through 1961-2 various public meetings began to be held. In February 1961 a joint conference of the Bahá'ís of two cities of Venice and Padua reviewed the progress of the religion there while a public meeting for the [[Bahá'í Naw-Rúz]] gathered Bahá'ís and guests from Bologna, Florence, Padua, [[Rimini]], and San Marino.{{Cite magazine| title = International News Briefs |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1961 | number = 363 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =18 | url =}} In October there were three events held to honor the United Nations. The first two were talks by Dr. Alessandro Bausani, member of the Italo-Swiss National Assembly and professor of oriental languages at the Universities of Rome and Naples, on the theme of "United Nations and a United World" in Florence and Bologna. The third event was [[Bahá'í administration#Auxiliary Boards|Auxiliary Board]] member Mario Piarulli who spoke in Padua about the UN before an international audience.{{Cite magazine| title = Energetic Italo-Swiss Community Prepares for the Climactic Ridvan|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1962 | number = 371 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =7 | url =}} A feature writer of the Socialist newspaper [[Avanti! (Italian newspaper)|Avanti]] interviewed Bausani, and then wrote an account, not only of the meeting but also of the religion in general.{{Cite magazine| title = Baha'i in the News |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1962 | number = 373 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =16 | url =}} A public initiative in Turin drew about eighty people from Genoa, Milan, and Turin to hear Ugo Giachery speak about his slide-illustrated recent visit to Central America. This was followed by a series of six public meetings to give anyone interested an opportunity to investigate the religion. The average attendance was about seventy. In Bologna a public meeting was held where the audience heard Dr. Giachery on "Bahá'í approaches to modern problems".{{Cite magazine| title = Teaching In Italy is Accelerated |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1962 | number = 378 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =14 | url =}} Another public meeting took place in Padua among youth.{{Cite magazine| title = Thirty-nine young people, of whom nine were non-Baha'is…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1962 | number = 380 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =6 | url =}} ==== Italian National Assembly and community snapshot ==== In 1962 the Italian Bahá'í community elected its own [[National Spiritual Assembly]]. Its first members were: David Ned Blackmer Hossein Mahboubi, Teresa Taffa, Augusto Robiati, Heshmat Moayyad, Mario Fiorentini, Manutcher Majzub, Hossein Avaregan, and Mario Piarulli.{{Cite magazine| title = Joy and Earnest Resolve Mingle at Conventions of Growing Latin-American National Communities|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1962 | number = 376 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=13–15| url =}} Bausani was a member of the National Spiritual Assembly of Italy for twenty years until 1984. A total of 141 Bahá'ís came to the first Italian summer school, held in September near Rimini. Non-Baha'is also participated in some of the classes. Hand of the Cause Ugo Giachery gave a talk on "The Historical, Religious and Literary Work of Shoghi Effendi."{{Cite magazine| title = European Summer Schools Drew Large Groups of Enthusiastic Youth and Adults|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1962 | number = 381 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=2–4 | url =}} In 1963 the members of the national assemblies then in existence were the delegates for the first election of the [[Universal House of Justice]]. The members of the Italian assembly were Professor Hossein Avaregan, Alessandro Bausani, David Ned Blackmer, Professor Mario Fiorentini, Manoutchehr Madjzoub, Hossein Mahboubi, Mario Piarulli, Augusto Robiati, and Teresa Taffa; six of whom were able to attend the convention itself.{{Cite book|editor-last= Rabbani |editor-first=Ruhiyyih |editor-link=Rúhíyyih Khanum |year= 1992 |title= The Ministry of the Custodians 1957-1963 |publisher= Bahá'í World Centre |page = 410 |isbn= 0-85398-350-X |url= http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians.html&chapter=7 }} The Bahá'í communities of Italy in 1963 were: {| class="wikitable" |- | Assemblies |- | [[Bari]] | [[Bologna]] | [[Florence]] | [[Genoa]] | [[Milan]] | [[Naples]] | [[Padua]] | [[Palermo]] | [[Perugia]] | [[Rome]] | [[Trieste]] | [[Turin]] | [[Venice]] |- | Groups |- | [[Cagliari]] | [[Como]] | [[Laterina]] | [[Mantua]] | [[Parma]] | [[Pisogne]] | [[Rimini]] | [[Siena]] |- | Isolated Bahá'ís |- | [[Ghiffa]] | [[Lecce]] | [[Mercatello sul Metauro]] | [[Messina]] | [[Meta, Campania|Meta]] | [[Pioltello]] | [[Pisa]] | [[Poggibonsi]] | [[Roncade]] | [[Sassari]] |} == Development as a national community == === Public meetings === In 1963 Bahá'í Mrs. Meherangiz Munsiff of England, formerly of India, toured six cities with Indian art and slides of temples and holy places.{{Cite magazine| title = Cooperative Effort Spurs Teaching in Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1963 | number = 389 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =10 | url =}} In 1965 the International Club of the University of Padua invited the Bahá'ís to give a talk on the religion. Human Rights Day observances with Bahá'ís were also scheduled in many Italian cities - Bologna, Mantua, Padua, Milan, Genova, Turin and Florence. In December 1966 the Bahá'ís of Milan held two public conferences with members of various cultural clubs, the Press Club and others.{{Cite magazine| title = The Bahá'ís of Milan, Italy held two conlerences |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1967 | number = 432 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =11 | url =}} Professor Bausani gave a presentation at the Cultural and Artistic Club of the [[University of Padua]] on religions that originated in Persia - the Bahá'í Faith in particular.{{Cite magazine| title = News Briefs|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1967 | number = 433 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =10 | url =}} In 1968 public meetings were held in [[Perugia]], Milan, [[Anacapri]],{{Cite magazine| title = Faith Reaches People of Italy in Many Ways |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1968 | number = 445 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =10 | url =}} and in Palermo at [[Fiera del Mediterraneo]].{{Cite magazine| title = Italian Cities Stirred by Teachers' Visits; Hand of the Cause of God Revisits Sardinia |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1968 | number = 450 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =10 | url =}} A public meeting for about 250 people was held at the town theater in Rimini in November 1968 with a piano recital and talk by Prof. Bausani.{{Cite magazine| title = Proclamation In Rimini, Italy Followed by Teaching Conference |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1968 | number = 455 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =6 | url =}} In May 1969 Prof. Bausani gave a talk at a public meeting in [[Lipari]] at which some 60 people attended - the subject was on "the atomic age and the crisis in today's society" and mentioned the religion.{{Cite magazine| title = Proclamation Conference In Lipari, Italy|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1969 | number = 463 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =17 | url =}} The series of events drew a week of attention in Mantova in November 1969. The aim was to reach the greater part of the population of the city and have the Faith known, at least in name. Copies of ''The Proclamation of Bahá'u'lláh'' were presented to leading local dignitaries and a number of events were held: public conferences, round-table discussions, a concert, and slide shows.{{Cite magazine| title = Proclamation Conference In Lipari, Italy|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1970 | number = 469 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =24 | url =}} [[World Religion Day]] was observed by the Bahá'ís in Rome with an interfaith public round table discussion at the [[Accademia Tiberina]] on the theme of "Religion as an instrument of peace and unity".{{Cite magazine| title = Italy - World Religion Day|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1970 | number = 474 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =16 | url =}} In May 1971 a public event was held on [[Ischia]] island with youth performers.{{Cite magazine| title = A New Consciousness in Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1971 | number = 468 | ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=4–5 | url =}} The Bahá'ís of Rimini held a conference in October 1975 in observance of [[International Women's Year]].{{Cite magazine| title =Around the World; Faith is discussed on TV talk program |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1976 | number = 538 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =18 | url =}} The city of Milan invited the Bahá'ís for a public presentation so the Bahá'ís organized a series of six lectures on various [[Bahá'í teachings]].{{Cite magazine| title =Around the World; Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1981 | number = 604 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =12 | url =}} === Youth opportunities === The 1964 summer school was held in Bellaria, [[Guy Murchie]] was among the teachers of that year.{{Cite magazine| title = Italian Youth Exhibit High Degree of Service at Summer School|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1964 | number = 405 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =2 | url =}} The 1965 Italian summer school was held again in Bellaria near Rimini. This year the committee doubled reserved rooms and did so for two weeks instead of one. Happily 284 Bahá'ís attended from sixteen countries and more than twenty non-Baha'is attended. Two Hands of the Cause were present to teach classes - [[John Ferraby]] ("The Charters of the Cause of God,") and [[Abu'l-Qásim Faizi]] ("The Meaning of History from the Bahá'í Point of View").{{Cite magazine| title = Italy Holds Two-Week School in Bellaria |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1965 | number = 417 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =6 | url =}} The following year among the presentators for the 287 students was Dr. [[Firuz Kazemzadeh]], former chairman of the National Assembly of the United States, and Prof. Alessandro Bausani, who, in addition to giving two courses, translated for the English, Persian and French speaking teachers.{{Cite magazine| title = Italian School Draws 287 to Adriatic Sea|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1966 | number = 429 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =11 | url =}} In 1965 the youth of Milan began holding weekend classes{{Cite magazine| title = Youth of Milan, Italy, who have formed…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1966 | number = 408 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =7 | url =}} and a national youth committee was operating.{{Cite magazine| title = New Avenues of Proclamation Open in Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1965 | number = 410 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =5 | url =}} A ''Youth Symposium'' was held at Rimini in March 1967 with over 120 attending; a graduate of the first training institute gave the public talk. The sixth Italian summer school took place at Contursi, near Naples, in September, 1967, with 169 participants from thirteen countries.{{Cite magazine| title = Villagers and Farmers Attend Italian Baha'i School |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1968 | number = 442 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =10 | url =}} Speakers and teachers of classes included Prof. Bausani and Dr. Giachery, Mr. Rosapepe, the attorney who obtained the recognition of the Faith in Italy and owner of the hotel where the school was held, Philip Hainsworth, member of the National Spiritual Assembly of the British Isles, Auxiliary Board member Dr. Eric Blumenthal, Augusto Robiati, Auxiliary Board member James Holmlund. The youth organized round-table discussions and afterwards a public conference was organized at the University Club. In the spring of 1968 the National Youth Committee of Italy organized a school at Passignano on the shores of [[Lake Trasimeno]] with 110 attendees.{{Cite magazine| title = Italian Youth School and Proclamation Events Forward Faith |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1968 | number = 448 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =6 | url =}} In September 1969 the seventh Italian Summer School took place at [[Igea Marina]]. Two Hands of the Cause of God, Dr. Adelbert Mlihlschlegel and Jalal Khazeh, three members of the Continental Board of Counsellors, Mrs. D. Ferraby, Mr. L. Henuzet, Dr. E. Blumenthal, as well as a professor of the University of Milan and a young assistant professor from the University of Florence.{{Cite magazine| title = ITALY - Seventh Italian Summer School|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1970 | number = 468 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =6 | url =}} The 1971 National Baha'i Youth School was held in [[Pisa]] in April and was followed by a public conference and in June a Youth Symposium in San Marino was used to plan participation in a continental conference as well as a public meeting. In 1975 group of about 170 attended the National Youth Symposium at Florence.{{Cite magazine| title = Around the World; Plans are pushed for youth campaign|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1975 | volume= 52| issue = 468 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =16 | url =}} An additional school was held in Vieste as well.{{Cite magazine| title = Around the World; Teaching emphasized at Summer School|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1975 | number= 537 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =16 | url =}} The September 1977 Bahá'í summer school was held in [[Giulianova]] - one of the speakers was [[Adib Taherzadeh]].{{Cite magazine| title = Around the World; 12 declarations highlight annual summer school|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1977 | number= 559 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =14 | url =}} He was a speaker at the 1978 school along with others and a special guest Dr. Pagnanelli, director of the information center of the United Nations Organization in Rome, gave a public talk on "The First 30 Years of the United Nations Organization."{{Cite magazine| title = Around the World; Blessed Beauty's life focus of Summer School |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1977 | number= 561 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =11 | url =}} Eight hundred-fifty people from 19 countries attended the 1983 Italian Bahá'í summer school in the southern city of [[Cosenza]]. Special guests at the school were the Hand of the Cause [[Rúhíyyih Khanum]], who was making her first visit to the Italian Bahá'í community. About 120 children attended special classes arranged for them by the Italian National Children's Committee.{{Cite magazine| title = Around the World; Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1984 | number= 561 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =15 | url =}} The ''Austrian Dawnbreakers'' toured seven cities in Italy, presenting five concerts, taping two television shows, and appearing at former member of the ensemble, in three schools.{{Cite magazine| title = Around the World; Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1985 | number= 652 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =14 | url =}} Students in a Bahá'í children's class in 1988 in Milan raised money to sponsor a child in Haiti by paying his tuition for a year at the [[Anís Zunúzí Bahá'í School]]. About 600 youth from 20 countries gathered for the European Bahá'í Youth Conference in San Marino including some 40 youth Bahá'ís from Turkey. Guest speakers included various ministers of government of San Marino and as covered on state television and six newspapers.{{Cite magazine| title = Around the World; Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1989 | number= 702 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =16 | url =}} === Flood relief === In response to the [[1966 Flood of the River Arno in Florence]] the National Spiritual Assembly of Italy appointed an ''Aid to Flood Victims Committee'' during the 1966 national conference on the progress of the religion in November.{{Cite magazine| title = Baha'is Provide Aid to Flood Victims of Italy|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1967 | number = 439 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =15 | url =}} The members were: Houshyar Achraf, Mohammad Ravanbakhs, Col. Giulio Jacoviello, Sohrab Payment, and Maud Bosio. The first check received for the fund was from the [[Universal House of Justice]]. City Hall furnished Letters of introduction to the Aid Centers of the most damaged districts in Florence and Brozzi. Before October 1967 a variety of assistance was provided: seventy-five families visited; fifty-nine families assisted with more than 1,600 garments; forty-eight families given bed linen, towels, etc.; twenty-seven woolen blankets furnished; beds, mattresses, pillows, electric stoves and furniture distributed. The sum of $735 (1967 dollars) was given as emergency help to twenty families. === Publications === In 1954 a translation of John Esslemont's ''Bahá'u'lláh and the New Era'' was published.{{Cite book| last = Esslemont| first = John | title = Bahá'u'lláh e la nuova era | publisher = Edizioni Bahai | year = 1954 | location = Rome, Italy | url = | doi = | id = | isbn =}} In 1956 a compilation of Bahá'u'lláh's writings was published as ''Spigolature dagli scritti''.{{Cite book| last = Bahá'u'lláh|first = | authorlink = Bahá'u'lláh| title = Spigolature dagli scritti | publisher = Edizioni Bahai| year = 1956 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }} On October 21, 1966, a review of the pamphlet, ''One God, One Truth, One People'', by Dr. Ugo Giachery, appeared in the Italian newspaper ''Il Secolo'' in Genoa Italy. It was positively reviewed by critic Nicola Ghiglione.{{Cite magazine| title = Baha'i in the News |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1967 | number = 431 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =19 | url =}} ''Relazioni Religiose'', a press information agency dealing exclusively with religious affairs and worldwide theological developments, announced in its bulletin of February 9, 1967 the legal recognition of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Italy in an article reviewing the religion entitled "The Religious Baha'i Community of Italy Obtains Juridical Recognition".{{Cite magazine| title = Baha'i in the News |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1967 | number = 436 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =27 | url =}} Augusto Robiati published a number of small books and articles in Italian including an introduction to the religion and about the role of assemblies and other works.{{Cite web| title = Augusto Robiati | work = | publisher = Augusto Robiati| url =http://www.augustorobiati.it/bio.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2010-02-20}} Two books in particular were Robiati's award-winning ''Uomo Svegliati'' (1973) and ''Gli Otto Veli''(1981). The first Italian edition in 1978 of [[The Dawn-Breakers]] was made available by the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Italy.{{Cite web |url=http://religione.bahaisalerno.it/?cat=8 |title=Presentazione de “gli Araldi dell’Aurora” |access-date=2010-03-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100313225415/http://religione.bahaisalerno.it/?cat=8 |archive-date=2010-03-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Julio Savi began to publish a number of books:''Bahíyyih Khánum Ancella di Bahá'' (1983),{{Cite web| last = Savi | first = Julio | authorlink = Julio Savi | title = books of Julio Savi | work = Website of Julio Savi | publisher = | url =http://www.juliosavi.it/eng/books-julio-savi.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2010-02-20}} and ''The Eternal Quest for God'' which was published in 1988 among them.{{Cite book| last = Savi | first = Julio | title = The Eternal Quest for God | publisher = George Ronald Publisher Ltd | location = | url =http://bahai-library.org/books/quest/introduction.html | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-85398-295-1}} Bausani's essays and articles were gathered together and published in one volume in 1991 by Casa Editrice Bahá'í (Roma) under the title: Saggi sulla Fede Bahá'í(Essays on the Bahá'í Faith). In 1991 a collection of essays about the Bahá'í Faith by Bausani was published.{{Cite book| last = Bausani | first = Alessandro |title = Saggi sulla fede Bahá'í | publisher = Casa Editrice Bahá'í | year = 1991 | location = Rome, Italy | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 88-7214-006-4}} Others of his texts are used in academic religious classes in 2010.[http://www.eng.unibo.it/PortaleEn/Academic+programmes/Teachings/dettaglio.htm?AnnoAccademico=2009&IdComponenteAF=158716&CodDocente=036124&CodMateria=02308 02308 - History of ReligionAcademic Year 2009/2010], Teacher Piras Andrea A 2001 book ''I Baha'i'' profiling the religion has been translated into Italian published through [[CESNUR]] (Centro Studi sulle Nuove Religion).{{Cite journal| last = Warburg | first = Margit |author2=trans. S. Salzani | title = I Baha'i | journal = La collana Religioni e Movimenti | volume = 2001 |page=128 | publisher = [[CESNUR]] (Centro Studi sulle Nuove Religion) | location = Turin| year = 2001 | url = http://www.ibs.it/code/9788801020854/warburg-margit/baha-i.html | isbn = | accessdate = 2010-02-23}} Bausani was director of the Italian quarterly magazine ''Opinioni Bahá'í'' from its foundation which was published under authority of the national assembly starting in 1977.{{Cite magazine| title = Around the World; Italian magazine published |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1977 | number = 554 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =14 | url =}} The National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Italy initiated the publication of a special booklet for [[International Year of the Child]] containing quotations from the Bahá'í scriptures on the education of children.{{Cite magazine| title = IYE Report - A worldwide round-up of Baha'í activities supporting the International Year of the Child; Ongoing Programs-4. Publications for and concerning Children |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1980 | number = 592 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =4 | url =}} === Socio-economic development projects === Since its inception the religion has had involvement in [[socio-economic development]] beginning by giving greater freedom to women,{{Cite web| last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran | work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com | url =http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development| accessdate = 2009-10-16}} promulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern,{{Cite journal| last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socio-economic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | year = 1997 | url =http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development }} and that involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics. The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the [[Universal House of Justice]] dated 20 October 1983 was released.{{Cite journal|title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen |author2=Smith, Peter | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8}} Bahá'ís were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the [[Bahá'í teachings]], in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities in which they lived. Worldwide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognized Bahá'í socio-economic development projects. By 1987, the number of officially recognized development projects had increased to 1482. Italian Association of Baha'i Studies in 1990. Baha'i Association of Socio-Economic Development named after Gianni Ballerio was established in 2003{{Cite web| title = Dove Siamo | work = Bahá’í Association for Social Advancement (Gianni Ballerio) | publisher = Cesvol Perugia | url = http://www.pgcesvol.com/bahai/en/dove.htm | accessdate = 2010-03-06}} and operates over forty projects across [[Regions of Italy]].{{Cite web| title = Initiatives | work = Bahá’í Association for Social Advancement (Gianni Ballerio) | publisher = Cesvol Perugia | url = http://www.pgcesvol.com/bahai/en/iniziative.htm | accessdate = 2010-03-06}} == Institutional and community development == More than forty youth attended the three-day conference in Florence that centered its discussion around specific challenges in Italy to the progress of the religion. Ugo Giachery met with youth and adult Bahá'ís in October and November.{{Cite magazine| title = Baha'is of Palermo, Sicily, with their friends |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1964 | number = 405 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =2 | url =}} The first Italian Bahá'í of Mantua was Aida Neva.{{Cite magazine| title = Public meeting held in Mantua, Italy… |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1965 | number = 415 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =7 | url =}} In 1966 there were a number of developments. The Italian National Spiritual Assembly was able to register as an incorporated foundation under Italian law.{{Cite journal|last =Pinna| first = Daniela | editor-last = Introvigne | editor-first = Massimo | title = Review of Margit Warburg's ''I Baha'i''| journal = Religioni e Movimenti (seconda serie) | volume = 2001 | issue = | publisher = [[CESNUR]] (Centro Studi sulle Nuove Religion)| location = Turin | date = 30 November 2001 | url =http://www.cesnur.org/recens/bahai_pinna.htm | issn = | doi = | id = | accessdate = 2010-02-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100222001141/http://www.cesnur.org/recens/bahai_pinna.htm| archivedate= 22 February 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{Cite magazine| title = Universal House of Justice Announces Incorporation of National Assembly in Italy |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1967 | number = 431 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =4 | url =}} The same year a gathering of Bahá'ís on Sardinia was coordinated and a talk given by Livia Pargentino, the first declared Sardinian Bahá'í.{{Cite magazine| title = Baha'i Weekend in Sardinia |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1966 | number = 429 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =16 | url =}} In 1966 two islands had their first pioneers- on the island of [[Capri]] it was Rouhaughy Fahteazam, and on the island of [[Lipari]] it was Teresa Taffa{{Cite magazine| title = The Horizon of Italy Expands |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1967 | number = 438 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =10 | url =}} while in Sardinia there was the first Sardinian conversion occurred when Livia Pargentino joined the religion. The first training institute for promulgating the religion in Italy was conducted by Mildred Mottahehdeh in February 1967.{{Cite magazine| title = First Italian teacher training institute… |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1966 | number = 434 | ISSN=0195-9212 | page =9 | url =}} In 1968 a Catholic monk, Padre Marian, mentioned the religion on his television program and read the prayer by 'Abdu'l-Bahá.{{Cite magazine| title = International News Briefs;
