{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Politics of Turkey}} The [[Social conflict|political conflict]] between the [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|AKP]]-ruled [[Turkish government]] and the [[Gülen Movement]] of [[Fethullah Gülen]] began in 2013. With similarities in ideology, the AKP and the Gülen Movement have long maintained an alliance, with the latter using their judicial influence to limit opposition from [[Turkey]]'s secular establishment to the AKP's [[religious conservatism]]. Traditionally cosy relations between the AKP government and the Gülen Movement turned sour in late 2013 after Gülen criticised the government's response to the [[Gezi Park protests]] and their policy of closing down Gülen's private [[Cram school#Turkey|"prep-schools"]].The so-called "prep-schools" were "weekend courses that prepare high school students for university exams".
{{cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/01/akp-gulen-conflict-guide.html#|title=What you should know about Turkey's AKP-Gulen conflict - Al-Monitor: the Pulse of the Middle East|work=Al-Monitor|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150424173852/http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/01/akp-gulen-conflict-guide.html|archivedate=24 April 2015|df=dmy-all}} The disagreement between the government and the movement escalated into a skirmish, with then-Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] accusing the Gülen Movement of trying to bring down the government by using their influence over the judiciary to cause a [[2013 corruption scandal in Turkey|government corruption scandal]] (known as the 17-25 investigations due to the dates on which it occurred).{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/yazarlar/murat_yetkin/erdogan_bindigi_dali_kesiyor_yolsuzluk_sorusturmasinin_yildonumu-1252926|title=Erdoğan bindiği dalı kesiyor: Yolsuzluk soruşturmasının yıldönümü|author=MURATYETKİN|work=Radikal}} The government subsequently responded with large-scale reforms to the police and judiciary forces to purge Gülen's sympathisers from their positions.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/01/turkey-police-detained|title=Turkish police detained over alleged plot to topple Erdoğan government|work=the Guardian}}{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/politika/erdogan_subaylara_seslendi_komutanlarin_tutuklanmasinda_aldatildik-1317305|title=Erdoğan subaylara seslendi: Komutanların tutuklanmasında aldatıldık|date=19 March 2015|work=Radikal}} The conflict has been referred to as a coup attempt by pro-AKP commentators and as a purge of judicial independence by critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25566536.asp|title=Başbakan Erdoğan: En ahlaksız darbe girişimi|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} Branding the movement as a '[[Parallel state|parallel structure]]' and accusing Gülen of setting up an 'armed terrorist group', the government's efforts to purge the influence of the Gülen Movement has become a mainstream issue in [[Turkish politics]] and has sparked nationwide concerns over judicial independence and growing government authoritarianism in Turkey.{{cite web|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/anasayfa_court-claims-armed-group-leadership-in-gulen-arrest-warrant-without-evidence_367811.html|title=Court claims armed group leadership in Gülen arrest warrant without evidence|date=23 December 2014|work=TodaysZaman}}{{cite web|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/anasayfa_eu-report-criticizes-turkey-over-judicial-independence-press-freedom_360994.html|title=EU report criticizes Turkey over judicial independence, press freedom|date=8 October 2014|work=TodaysZaman}} ==Background== [[File:Fethullah Gülen visiting Ioannes Paulus II.jpg|235px|thumbnail|right|[[Fethullah Gülen]] visiting [[Pope John Paul II]] in 1998]] Relations between the [[Turkish government]] and the Gülen Movement date back to the premiership of [[Turgut Özal]], who took office in 1983. The leader of the movement, Fethullah Gülen, has resided in [[Pennsylvania]] since 1999. Originating from a series of conferences and schools, the Movement gradually increased its influence in both the Turkish political and justice systems, with many of Gülen's supporters ending up occupying senior positions in the [[Judiciary of Turkey|Judiciary]]. The Movement's influence in the Turkish government culminated in bringing forward the highly controversial [[Ergenekon trials|Ergenekon]] and the [[Sledgehammer (coup plan)|Sledgehammer]] court cases against critics of the governing [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party (AKP)]] in 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/hanefi-avci-blames-gulen-movement-government-for-balyoz-ergenekon-cases-.aspx?pageID=238&nID=68498&NewsCatID=338|title=Hanefi Avcı blames Gülen movement, government for Balyoz, Ergenekon cases - POLITICS|work=hurriyetdailynews.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazetevatan.com/rusen-cakir-650418-yazar-yazisi-balyoz-gulen-cemaatinin-basin-d-a-patladi/|title=Balyoz Gülen cemaatinin başın(d)a patladı|work=gazetevatan.com}} The Gülen Movement's leader, Fethullah Gülen, managed to maintain a large number of supporters worldwide through the use of sympathetic media outlets, events, religious schools and charities. Several companies and organisations are affiliated with the movement, such as [[Samanyolu TV]] and [[Bank Asya]].{{cite web|url=http://www.samanyoluhaber.com/web-tv/Hizmet-Hareketi--video-haberleri/|title=Samanyolu Haber Web TV Hizmet-Hareketi videoları izle ve seyret|work=samanyoluhaber.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.internethaber.com/bank-asyaya-son-destek-fethullah-gulenden-763372h.htm|title=Haber : Bank Asya'ya son destek Fethullah Gülen'den haberi|work=Internethaber}} The movement is also supported by numerous political parties, mostly by the AKP between 2002 and 2013. Smaller parties such as the [[Democratic Progress Party]] and the [[Nation and Justice Party]] have also been accused of being sympathetic to Gülen's cause.{{cite web|url=http://www.sabah.com.tr/gundem/2015/03/18/paralel-orgut-tabela-partilerini-kullanip-atti|title=Paralel örgüt tabela partilerini kullanıp attı|date=18 March 2015|work=Sabah}} The main opposition [[Republican People's Party (Turkey)|Republican People's Party]] was accused of maintaining informal links with the movement during the [[Turkish local elections, 2014|2014 local elections]].{{cite web|url=http://www.takvim.com.tr/guncel/2014/12/14/chpli-vekilden-paralel-yapi-itirafi|title=CHP'li vekilden paralel yapı itirafı!|work=takvim.com.tr}} [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] ex-MPs, such as [[Hakan Şükür]], are also seen as staunch followers of the movement.{{cite web|url=http://www.bugun.com.tr/gundem/bomba-aciklama-haberi/1327858|title=Hakan Şükür: İstifa ettiğim gün bakanlık teklif ettiler|work=Bugun.com.tr}} ==Belligerents== {{unreferenced section|date=June 2015}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! width=460px| [[Turkey|Turkish state]] !! width=460px|[[Gülen Movement]] |- ! colspan="2"|Government and state |- | [[Cabinet Erdoğan III|61st Government of Turkey]] || Senior members of the [[Judiciary of Turkey|Turkish Judiciary]] |- | [[First Davutoğlu Cabinet|62nd Government of Turkey]] || Allegedly 2,000 members of the [[General Directorate of Security]] |- | [[General Directorate of Security]] || Schools and [[cram school]]s |- | [[Supreme Board of Judges and Prosecutors]] {{small|(since 2015)}} || A small number of government [[Member of Parliament#Turkey|Members of Parliament]] |- | [[National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)|National Intelligence Organisation]] (MİT) || |- ! colspan="2"|Political parties and organisations |- | [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party]] {{small|(since 2013)}} || [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party]] {{small|(before 2013)}} |- | [[Republican People's Party (Turkey)|Republican People's Party]] {{small|(2002-2014, 2015 onwards)}} || [[Republican People's Party (Turkey)|Republican People's Party]] {{small|(briefly, allegedly in 2014)}} |- | [[Rights and Equality Party]] || [[Democratic Progress Party]] {{small|(alleged)}} |- | [[Patriotic Party (Turkey)|Patriotic Party]]{{cite web|url=http://www.gazeteciler.com/tv-haber/unlu-spiker-mehpare-celikten-gulen-icin-sok-sozler-87089h.html|title=Ünlü spiker Mehpare Çelik'ten Gülen için şok sözler!|work=gazeteciler.com}} || [[Nation and Justice Party]] {{small|(alleged)}} |- | [[Independent Turkey Party]]{{cite web|url=http://www.timeturk.com/tr/2015/04/03/mit-raporunda-fethullah-gulen-haydar-bas-kavgasi.html|title=MİT raporunda Fethullah Gülen- Haydar Baş kavgası!|work=timeturk.com}} || [[Felicity Party]]{{cite web|url=http://www.sabah.com.tr/gundem/2014/03/05/saadetin-cemaate-destegini-hazmedemeyiz|title=Saadet'in Cemaat'e desteğini hazmedemeyiz - Gündem Haberleri|date=5 March 2014|work=Sabah}} |- ! colspan=2|[[List of newspapers in Turkey|Media]] and companies |- | ''[[Sabah (newspaper)|Sabah]]'' || ''[[Zaman (newspaper)|Zaman]]'' |- | ''[[Yeni Şafak]]'' || ''[[Taraf]]'' {{small|(some columnists)}} |- | ''[[Yeni Akit]]'' || ''[[Bugün]]'' |- | ''Star'' || ''[[Millet]]'' |- | ''[[Akşam]]'' || [[Samanyolu TV]] |- | ''[[Türkiye]]'' || [[Samanyolu Haber TV]] |- | ''Milat'' || Mehtap TV |- | [[Turkish Radio and Television Corporation|TRT]] || [[Bank Asya]] |- | Beyaz TV || rowspan=4 | |- | [[TV8 (Turkey)|TV8]] |- | [[NTV (Turkey)|NTV]] |- | [[Kanal 7]] |- ! colspan=2| Key people |- | [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] {{small|(Prime Minister, President)}} || [[Fethullah Gülen]] |- | [[Ahmet Davutoğlu]] {{small|(Foreign Minister, Prime Minister)}} || [[Ekrem Dumanlı]] |- | [[Abdullah Gül]] {{small|(President)}} || {{ill|Hidayet Karaca|tr|Hidayet Karaca}} |- | [[Emrullah İşler]] {{small|(Deputy Prime Minister)}} || [[Erhan Bilgili]] |- | [[Bülent Arınç]] {{small|(Deputy Prime Minister)}} || [[Ahmet Beyaz]] |- | [[Bekir Bozdağ]] {{small|(Justice Minister)}} || [[Hakan Şükür]] |- | [[Kenan İpek]] {{small|(Justice Minister)}} || [[İdris Bal]] {{small|(alleged)}} |- | [[Hakan Fidan]] {{small|(MİT Undersecretary)}} || [[İdris Naim Şahin]] {{small|(alleged)}} |} ==Start of the conflict== ===2012 allegations=== The first signs of a conflict came in February 2012, where the request for the [[National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)|National Intelligence Organisation]] (MİT) undersecretary [[Hakan Fidan]] to give evidence regarding the promotion of several AKP politicians known to be close to the Gülen Movement. In response to these claims, AKP deputy leader [[Hüseyin Çelik]] claimed that 'crows would laugh' at allegations that the Gülen Movement had taken over the state.{{cite web|url=http://www.ntvmsnbc.com/id/25323806|title='Cemaat devlete sızmış, buna kargalar güler'|date=20 February 2012|work=NTV}} ===Gezi Park protests=== {{main article|Gezi Park protests}} [[File:2013 Taksim Gezi Park protests (15th June).jpg|235px|thumbnail|right|Protestors at [[Taksim Square]], [[Istanbul]] on 15 June]] After environmentalists protests in [[Gezi Park]], [[Taksim Square]] turned into general protests against government authoritarianism in June 2013, Gülen began making statements from Pennsylvania that were regarded as some to be critical of the government's perceived heavy handed response.{{cite web|url=http://www.habervaktim.com/haber/329704/gulenden-gezi-parki-aciklamasi.html|title=Gülen'den Gezi Parkı Açıklaması|date=11 June 2013|work=Habervaktim}}{{cite web|url=http://www.internethaber.com/gulenden-herkese-elestiri-544000h.htm|title=Haber : Gülen'den yeni Gezi Parkı yorumu haberi|work=Internethaber}} These were seen as the first major signs that the alliance between the AKP and the Gülen Movement were waning. The government's response to the protestors were criticised internationally, with the [[United States]] condemning the disproportionate violence and the [[European Union]] stalling [[Accession of Turkey to the European Union|Turkey's accession negotiations]]. Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] refused to negotiate with protestors, calling them 'a handful of looters' and accusing several protestors of backing violent terrorist groups such as [[DHKP-C]]. In response, Gülen released a statement claiming that the future of a park was not worth a life, calling for both sides to end their respective struggles and negotiate in a peaceful manner.{{cite web|url=http://www.bugun.com.tr/gundem/avm-bir-can-eder-miydi-haberi/1025261|title=Fethullah Gülen Hocaefendi'den Gezi yorumu|work=Bugun.com.tr}} ==Cram school ''(dershane)'' crisis== {{see also|Cram school#Turkey}} The conflict between the AKP and the Gülen Movement was fully underway after the government proposed a new law that would force several private [[cram school]]s, many of which are owned by the Gülen Movement, to close.{{cite web|url=http://www.samanyoluhaber.com/egitim/Nabi-Avcidan-dershane-aciklamasi/1023884/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130815092051/http://www.samanyoluhaber.com/egitim/Nabi-Avcidan-dershane-aciklamasi/1023884/|title=Avcı: Dershanelerin dönüşümü 2014-2015 döneminde geçerli olacak|archivedate=15 August 2013|work=samanyoluhaber.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aktifhaber.com/erdogan-dershaneler-kapatilacak-geri-adim-yok-878860h.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304172917/http://www.aktifhaber.com/erdogan-dershaneler-kapatilacak-geri-adim-yok-878860h.htm|title=Erdoğan: Dershaneler Kapatılacak, Geri Adım Yok|date=4 November 2013|archivedate=4 March 2014|work=aktifhaber.com}} In response, the pro-Gülen media began a strong campaign against the government's proposals.{{cite web|url=http://www.zaman.com.tr/ekrem-dumanli/dershaneler-kapanir-ama-kapatilamaz_2168670.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222013758/http://www.zaman.com.tr/ekrem-dumanli/dershaneler-kapanir-ama-kapatilamaz_2168670.html|title=Dershaneler kapanır ama kapatılamaz!|author=Ekrem Dumanlı|archivedate=22 February 2014|work=ZAMAN}}{{cite web|url=http://www.zaman.com.tr/gundem_dershaneleri-kapatma-gerekceleri-inandirici-degil_2168182.html|title=Dershaneleri kapatma gerekçeleri inandırıcı değil|author=UĞUR SAĞINDIK|date=16 November 2013|work=ZAMAN}}{{cite web|url=http://www.zaman.com.tr/yorum_dershanelerin-kapatilmasi-ve-egitimin-gelecegindeki-kaos_2178211.html|title=Dershanelerin kapatılması ve eğitimin geleceğindeki kaos|author=OSMAN ABALI*|date=6 December 2013|work=ZAMAN}} The ''[[Zaman (newspaper)|Zaman]]'' newspaper, which is the most prominent pro-Gulen newspaper in Turkey and also one of the most widely circulated, carried headlines such as '''An educational coup''' and '''Such a law was never even seen in the [[1980 Turkish coup d'état|coup years]]'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/zaman/2013-11-14|title=Zaman Gazetesi - 14 Kasım 2013|work=gazete5.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/zaman/2013-11-15|title=Zaman Gazetesi - 15 Kasım 2013|work=gazete5.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/zaman/2013-11-16|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304175756/http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/zaman/2013-11-16|title=Zaman Gazete Manşeti 16 Kasım 2013|archivedate=4 March 2014|work=gazete5.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/zaman/2013-11-16|title=Zaman Gazetesi - 16 Kasım 2013|work=gazete5.com}} Furthermore, the paper claimed that not even the employment sector wanted the colleges to be forcefully closed and also printed 1.5 million copies of a special edition accompanied by an additional brochure entitled 'Cram School' ''(Dershane)''.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/zaman/2013-11-17|title=Zaman Gazetesi - 17 Kasım 2013|work=gazete5.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/zaman/2013-11-18|title=Zaman Gazetesi - 18 Kasım 2013|work=gazete5.com}} In response to ''Zaman's'' campaign, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdoğan reiterated that his cabinet had agreed to put the new legislation to [[Grand National Assembly|Parliament]] in November 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/egitim/25170010.asp|title=Başbakan Erdoğan: Dershaneleri kapatma kararı Bakanlar Kurulu ve Meclis’ten geçecek|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} Ekrem Dumanlı, the general circulation manager of ''Zaman'', wrote an open letter to Erdoğan in his column on 25 November 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.zaman.com.tr/ekrem-dumanli/basbakana-acik-mektup_2172283.html|title=BAŞBAKAN’A AÇIK MEKTUP|author=Ekrem Dumanlı|date=25 November 2013|work=ZAMAN}} On the same day, Fethullah Gülen himself released a statement entitled 'We will go on without stopping!'.{{cite web|url=http://www.herkul.org/bamteli/hic-durmadan-yuruyeceksiniz/|title=Hiç Durmadan Yürüyeceksiniz!..|work=Fethullah Gülen Hocaefendi'nin sohbetleri.}} The law received parliamentary approval in February 2014 and took effect a year later in February 2015.{{cite web|url=http://sozcu.com.tr/2014/genel/akpden-dersane-hamlesi-453349/|title=AKP’den dersane hamlesi!|date=6 February 2014|work=sozcu.com.tr}} ===2004 MGK controversy=== [[File:Milli Güvenlik Kurulu Sekreterliği Binası.jpg|235px|thumbnail|right|The [[National Security Council (Turkey)|National Security Council]] (MGK) building in [[Ankara]]]] While the controversy was ongoing, editor Mehmet Baransu from the ''[[Taraf]]'' newspaper wrote an article on 28 November 2013 claiming that the decision to bring down the Gülen Movement had in fact been taken during a [[National Security Council (Turkey)|National Security Council (MGK)]] meeting in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.taraf.com.tr/haber-gulen-i-bitirme-karari-2004-te-mgk-da-alindi-140671/|title=Gülen’i bitirme kararı 2004’te MGK’da alındı|work=taraf.com.tr}} The article claimed that the formal decision to end the movement's political influence had been signed in August 2004 by both Prime Minister Erdoğan and President [[Abdullah Gül]]. Erdoğan's chief advisor [[Yalçın Akdoğan]] denied the claims, but his denial failed to convince the pro-Gulen media.{{cite web|url=http://www.sabah.com.tr/Gundem/2013/11/30/2004-mgk-karari-yok-hukmundedir|title=2004 MGK kararı yok hükmündedir|date=30 November 2013|work=Sabah}} [[Samanyolu TV]] alleged that a decision for the [[National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)|National Intelligence Organisation]] to maintain surveillance on individuals was included in the leaked documents.{{cite web|url=http://www.samanyoluhaber.com/politika/Basbakan-Erdogan-MGK-belgelerinin-dogrulugunu-kabul-etti/1035338/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304183111/http://www.samanyoluhaber.com/politika/Basbakan-Erdogan-MGK-belgelerinin-dogrulugunu-kabul-etti/1035338/|title=Başbakan Erdoğan MGK belgelerinin doğruluğunu kabul etti|archivedate=4 March 2014|work=samanyoluhaber.com}} In response to the leaking of MGK documents, Prime Minister Erdoğan made a statement reiterating his decision to abolish cram schools, while slamming the leak as an [[treason|act of national treason]].{{cite web|url=http://www.zaman.com.tr/gundem_tarafin-sok-mgk-belgesi-gundemi-sarsti_2174649.html|title=Taraf'ın şok MGK belgesi gündemi sarstı|date=29 November 2013|work=ZAMAN}}{{cite web|url=http://haber.stargazete.com/politika/basbakan-erdogan-3b-vatana-ihanettir-dedi/haber-813682|title=Star Gazetesi, Star, Son Dakika Haberler, Güncel Haberler, Gazeteler|work=Star}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ekoayrinti.com/news_detail.php?id=138009|title=Erdoğan 2004 MGK kararları için suskunluğunu bozdu - Ekonomi Haberleri I Türkiye'nin en saygın ekonomi ve iş dünyası sitesi|work=ekoayrinti.com}} ===Resignation of AKP MPs=== The cram school crisis created a split within the AKP's parliamentary group, with pro-Gulen MPs openly voicing their concern over the new educational legislation. These included [[İdris Bal]], who vocally criticised his party's policy on cram schools and was subsequently referred to the party's disciplinary board for suspension. In statements made to the press, Bal had claimed that closing cram schools would mean many youths would be unable to make it to [[university]].{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/politika/akpli_vekil_icin_kesin_ihrac_istendi-1162111|title=Dershane tartışması vekil götürüyor: AKP'li İdris Bal için kesin ihraç istendi|date=20 November 2013|work=Radikal}} When his imminent suspension became certain, Bal resigned from the AKP.{{cite web|url=http://www.ntv.com.tr/arsiv/id/25482993|title=NTV Haber – Son Dakika Haberleri ve Güncel Haberler - Ntv.com.tr|work=ntv.com.tr}} He later formed the [[Democratic Progress Party]] (DGP) in November 2014, with many media outlets describing the party as the party of the Gulen Movement.{{cite web|url=http://www.ntv.com.tr/arsiv/id/25548467/|title=İdris Bal parti kurdu|date=5 November 2014|work=NTV}}{{cite web|url=http://www.zaman.com.tr/politika_dgp-genel-baskani-idris-bal-2015-secimlerine-girecegiz_2255675.html|title=DGP Genel Başkanı İdris Bal: 2015 seçimlerine gireceğiz|author=ALİCAN YILMAZ|date=5 November 2014|work=ZAMAN}} Before the [[Turkish general election, June 2015|June 2015 general election]] however, Bal resigned as the leader of his new party, accusing the pro-Gulen media of limiting his party's ability to reach out to voters.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/28607213.asp|title=İdris Bal, Demokratik Gelişim Partisi'nden istifa etti|author=Fırat KESKİNKILIÇ/ANKARA (DHA)|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} This cast doubt over initial claims that the DGP was a pro-Gulen political party. Another key resignation was that of [[Hakan Şükür]] in December 2013, who is openly a follower of Gulen and strongly critical of his party's cram school policy.{{cite web|url=http://siyaset.milliyet.com.tr/hakan-sukur-ak-parti-den-istifa/siyaset/detay/1808405/default.htm|title=Hakan Şükür AK Parti'den istifa etti|date=16 December 2013|work=milliyet.com.tr}} Şükür revealed after his resignation that he had been to visit Gulen on numerous occasions while still an AKP Member of Parliament, telling Gulen that he wanted to resign from his party. He claimed that Gulen had delayed his decision.{{cite web|url=http://www.haberturk.com/gundem/haber/908682-hocaefendiye-gittim-bana-dedi-ki|title=Hocaefendi'ye gittim, bana dedi ki...|date=2 January 2014|work=www.haberturk.com}} ==2013 government corruption scandal== {{main article|2013 corruption scandal in Turkey}} ===17 December operations=== On 17 December 2013, a wave of arrests targeting businessmen, bankers and most notably the sons of four serving cabinet ministers in Erdoğan's government were arrested during an anti-corruption operation.{{cite web|url=http://www.haberturk.com/gundem/haber/904362-iste-gozaltina-alinan-isimler|title=İşte gözaltına alınan isimler!|date=18 December 2013|work=www.haberturk.com}} The allegations that a banknote counting machine had been found in serving Interior Minister [[Muammer Güler|Muammer Güler's]] son's house, as well as the revelation that large amounts of money had been hidden in shoe boxes in the house of the CEO of [[Halkbank]] caused a media storm.{{cite web|url=http://webtv.hurriyet.com.tr/2/58162/0/1/banka-mudurunun-evindeki-ayakkabi-kutusunda-4-5-milyon-dolar.aspx|title=BANKA MÜDÜRÜNÜN EVİNDEKİ AYAKKABI KUTUSUNDA 4,5 MİLYON DOLAR|work=hurriyettv}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25390528.asp|title=Barış Güler'in evindeki aramadan ilk görüntüler|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} A total of 80 people were arrested, with 24 formally charged.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25387147.asp|title=Kod adı: Büyük rüşvet|author=Operasyon İzleme Ekibi: Çetin AYDIN - Eyüp SERBEST - Mustafa KÜÇÜK - Ali DAĞLAR - Ayşegül USTA - Şehriban OĞHAN - İpek YEZDANİ - Aziz ÖZEN - Fevzi KIZILKOYUN - Erdinç ÇELİKKAN - Hacer BOYACIOĞLU / İSTANBUL - ANKARA|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} Following the anti-corruption operations, Deputy Prime Minister [[Bülent Arınç]] issued a statement saying that the government knew who was behind the operations and that any intervention of a group within the governance of the state would be dealt with accordingly.{{cite web|url=http://www.internethaber.com/arinctan-flas-operasyon-aciklamasi-620192h.htm|title=Arınç'tan flaş operasyon açıklaması!|work=Internethaber}} Erdoğan called the arrests a 'dirty operation'.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/turkce/haberler/131218_canli_operasyon.shtml|title=Erdoğan 'kirli operasyon' dedi; emniyette görevden almalar yaşandı|work=BBC Türkçe}} On the same day as the operation, five branch managers from the Istanbul Directorate of Security were removed from their posts.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25387740.asp|title=İstanbul Emniyeti'nde şok|author=Çetin Aydın / İstanbul|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} Two new prosecutors, Ekrem Aydıner and Mustafa Erol, were assigned to deal with the corruption cases, alongside the existing two prosecutors Celal Kara and Mehmet Yüzgeç due to the extensiveness of the case.{{cn|date=January 2018}} Kara and Yüzgeç, the two existing prosecutors, were late removed from the case. Mustafa Erol later resigned from the case.{{cite web|url=http://www.haberturk.com/gundem/haber/916794-17-aralik-sorusturmasinda-flas-gelisme|title=17 Aralık soruşturmasında flaş gelişme|date=29 January 2014|work=www.haberturk.com}} The entire corruption investigation was subsequently dealt by a single prosecutor, namely Ekrem Aydıner. The fact that only one prosecutor was now presiding over a case where two prosecutors had originally been assigned due to a heavy workload led to allegations that Aydıner was acting on the in favour of the government's demands.{{cite web|url=http://www.evrensel.net/haber/78491/savci-ekrem-aydinere-ne-vadedildi.html|title=Savcı Ekrem Aydıner'e ne vadedildi?|work=Evrensel.net}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25814779.asp|title=Tanrıkulu'ndan Başbakan'a "Savcı Ekrem Aydıner" sorusu|author=DHA|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} Following the operation, the government branded the investigation as a 'planned psychological attack', 'an illegal group within the state' and 'dirty games being played within and outside the Turkish state'.{{cite web|url=http://yenisafak.com.tr/politika-haber/psikolojik-harp-var-19.12.2013-594913|title=Psikolojik harp var|author=Piri Medya|date=18 December 2013|work=Yeni Şafak}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/star/2013-12-18|title=Star Gazetesi - 18 Aralık 2013|work=gazete5.com}} While the government did not name the Gulen Movement specifically, Gulen recorded a message full of religious imprecations.{{cite web|url=http://webtv.hurriyet.com.tr/2/58316/0/1/iste-gulen-in-sinirlendigi-anlar.aspx|title=İŞTE GÜLEN'İN SİNİRLENDİĞİ ANLAR|work=hurriyettv}} Most media and political commentators claimed that the government's accusations were clearly directed at either the Gulen Movement, or a segment within the Gulen Movement.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/yazarlar/25437545.asp|title=Erdoğan’ın Fethullah Hoca söyleminin şifreleri|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}}{{cite news |url=http://haber.stargazete.com/acikgorus/gulen-cemaati-ve--7csunni-kodlarin-kaybi/haber-822278|title=Gülen Cemaati ve Sünni kodların kaybı | date=12 December 2013 | language=tr | work=Star Açık Görüş| accessdate=15 August 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://haber.stargazete.com/yazar/bir-kuskumuz-var/yazi-825948|title=Bir kuşkumuz var...|author=Fehmi KORU, Star Gazetesi|work=Star.com.tr}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/yazarlar/25513485.asp|title=Bir ‘paralel cemaat’ de mi var?|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} The movement had by now been branded a '[[Parallel state|parallel structure]]' operating within the state. ===Cabinet reshuffle and resignations=== The three ministers that were incriminated in the corruption scandal, namely [[Zafer Çağlayan]], [[Erdoğan Bayraktar]] and [[Muammer Güler]], resigned from their cabinet ministers. Having also been mentioned in the corruption investigations, [[Egemen Bağış]] also lost his position in the ensuring reshuffle. Bayraktar called for the Prime Minister to resign to ease the political tensions that had resulted from the corruption scandal, though later apologised for his statement.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25728382.asp|title=Bayraktar: Özür dilerim|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25444272.asp|title=Başbakan da istifa etmeli|author=ANKARA|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} As a result of his party's perceived corruption, former Interior minister [[İdris Naim Şahin]] resigned from his party and called for the Prime Minister to resign. Şahin later established the [[Nation and Justice Party]] (MİLAD Party) in November 2014, with this party also being branded as pro-Gulen by media outlets close to the AKP. Şahin, like former DGP leader İdris Bal, resigned from his party before the 2015 general election after failing to seal an alliance deal with the [[Felicity Party]] and the [[Great Union Party]]. On 27 December 2015, [[Ertuğrul Günay]], [[Haluk Özdalga]] and Erdal Kalkan all resigned from the AKP. ===HSYK controversy and 25 December operation=== Realising that the ministers involved in the 17 December operations did not initially know that investigations had begun into them, the government made it compulsory for such investigations to be reported to the most senior officials in government.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25412900.asp|title=Adli Kolluk Yönetmeliği'nde değişiklik yapıldı|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} The [[Supreme Board of Judges and Prosecutors]] (HSYK) ruled this requirement [[Constitution of Turkey|unconstitutional]].{{cite web|url=http://www.zaman.com.tr/gundem_hsyk-yonetmelik-anayasaya-aykiri_2189373.html|title=HSYK: YÖNETMELİK ANAYASA'YA AYKIRI|date=26 December 2013|work=ZAMAN}} On 25 December, the same day that the HSYK ruled that the government's demands were unconstitutional, prosecutor Muammer Akkaş issued an arrest warrant for 30 more individuals on charges of corruption, yet the Istanbul Directorate of Security refused to make the arrests.{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/savci_polis_seflerine_soz_geciremedi-1168041|title=Savcı, polis şeflerine söz geçiremedi!|date=25 December 2013|work=Radikal}} As a result, Akkaş issued a statement claiming that he was being prevented from doing his job. The government responded by accusing Akkaş of attempting to begin a second operation through unlawful means, thus taking him off the case and allegedly giving it to prosecutor Turan Çolakkadı.{{cite web|url=http://www.sabah.com.tr/Gundem/2013/12/27/o-savci-bakin-kim-cikti|title=O savcı bakın kim çıktı?|date=26 December 2013|work=Sabah}} In the end, the case was transferred to five other prosecutors.{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/iste_o_dosyanin_yeni_savcilari-1168306|title=İşte o dosyanın yeni savcıları|date=26 December 2013|work=Radikal}} On 26 December, Prime Minister Erdoğan claimed that Akkaş had disgraced the judiciary by issuing such a statement and claimed that the HSYK had committed a crime by refusing the government's demands to notify senior ministers of investigations. He claimed that had he had the right, he would have 'tried' the HSYK himself, but claimed that the people would have the right to judge.{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/politika/basbakan_sakaryada_konusuyor-1168288|title=Başbakan Erdoğan: Millet bu HSYK'yı yargılayacak|date=26 December 2013|work=Radikal}} A day later, the [[Turkish Council of State]] voted down the government's demands, with Erdoğan subsequently issuing a statement saying 'what needs to be done will be done, and then you will see' and claiming that the judicial changes proposed in the [[Turkish constitutional referendum, 2010|2010 constitutional referendum]] had been a mistake.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25465765.asp|title=Erdoğan: 'Orada bir yanlış yaptık'|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} Several pro-government ministers claimed that the judicial setback was the last open attack against the AKP by the Gulen Movement.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/yeni-safak/2013-12-28|title=Yeni Şafak Gazetesi - 28 Aralık 2013|work=gazete5.com}} A new law that would bring the HSYK directly under the control of the [[Ministry of Justice (Turkey)|Ministry of Justice]] was passed on 1 February 2014 despite several breakouts of violence between government and opposition MPs.{{cite web|url=http://www.sabah.com.tr/Gundem/2014/02/15/hsyk-duzenlemesi-meclisten-gecti|title=HSYK düzenlemesi Meclis'ten geçti|date=15 February 2014|work=Sabah}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25519776.asp|title=AK Parti'den HSYK teklifi|author=Oya ARMUTÇU/ANKARA|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25548282.asp|title=Meclis'te yine HSYK kavgası|author=Oya ARMUTÇU / ANKARA|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} ===Accusations of a 'judicial coup'=== On 31 December, Deputy Prime Minister [[Ali Babacan]], who was later himself accused of being a supporter of Gulen, claimed that the events of 17 December 2013 had been a mini-coup attempt.{{cite web|url=http://www.ntvmsnbc.com/id/25489016/|title=NTV Haber – Son Dakika Haberleri ve Güncel Haberler - Ntv.com.tr|work=ntvmsnbc.com}} An intelligence report for the Prime Minister was leaked on the same day, with claims that the 'parallel structure' had branches in 27 [[Provinces of Turkey|provinces]] and had over 2,000 police officers and several academics, journalists and bankers under its control.{{cite web|url=http://www.ntvmsnbc.com/id/25489229/|title=Başbakan'a 2 bin kişilik 'paralel yapı' raporu|date=1 January 2014|work=NTV}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aksam.com.tr/guncel/42-ilde-cadi-avi-son-anda-engellendi-c2/haber-272825|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231123439/http://www.aksam.com.tr/guncel/42-ilde-cadi-avi-son-anda-engellendi-c2/haber-272825|title=42 ilde 'cadı avı' son anda engellendi |date=31 December 2013|archivedate=31 December 2013|work=aksam.com.tr}} President Abdullah Gül issued a statement on 4 January 2014 claiming that a state within a state was 'absolutely unacceptable'.{{cite web|url=http://www.sabah.com.tr/Gundem/2014/01/04/devlet-icinde-devlet-olamaz|title='Devlet içinde devlet olamaz'|date=4 January 2014|work=Sabah}} Erdoğan claimed that the corruption scandal had been an attempt to tarnish the AKP's image, to worsen his relations with President Gül, to sabotage the ongoing [[solution process]] with [[PKK|Kurdish rebels]] and to stop Turkey's growth. A new spate of anti-corruption operations began on 7 January, in provinces such as [[İzmir]], [[Amasya]] and [[İstanbul]]. These operations were mocked by the pro-AKP media.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/sabah/2014-01-05|title=Sabah Gazetesi - 5 Ocak 2014|work=gazete5.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.zaman.com.tr/politika_istanbulda-yeni-yolsuzluk-operasyonu_2193784.html|title=İstanbul'da yeni yolsuzluk operasyonu|author=OSMAN ARSLAN -CİHAN|date=16 January 2014|work=ZAMAN}}{{cite web|url=http://sozcu.com.tr/2014/gunun-icinden/yeni-yolsuzluk-operasyonu-445031/|title=Yeni yolsuzluk operasyonu|date=21 January 2014|work=sozcu.com.tr}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cumhuriyet.com.tr/haber/turkiye/32271/istanbul_da_yeni_yolsuzluk_operasyonu_.html|title=Cumhuriyet Gazetesi - İstanbul'da yeni yolsuzluk operasyonu!|date=22 January 2014|work=cumhuriyet.com.tr}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/sabah/2014-01-08|title=Sabah Gazetesi - 8 Ocak 2014|work=gazete5.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/yeni-safak/2014-01-08|title=Yeni Şafak Gazetesi - 8 Ocak 2014|work=gazete5.com}} ==MİT lorry scandal== {{main article|2014 National Intelligence Organisation scandal in Turkey}} On 1 January, lorries allegedly carrying weapons and bound for [[Syria]] were stopped in [[Adana]], while a similar convoy of lorries were stopped on 19 June in [[Hatay]]. The prosecutor Aziz Takçı, who ordered the lorries to be stopped and searched for weapons after receiving a tip-off, was later removed from his position and branded as a member of Gulen's 'parallel structure'. The government attempted to cover up the lorries' cargo and to stop the searching of their contents on both occasions, with it becoming apparent that they belonged to the [[National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)|National Intelligence Organisation]] (MİT). The accusation that MİT lorries were carrying weapons into Syria created yet another scandal, especially at a time when the government in the centre of international controversy for their policy of inaction against [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State militants]]. Erdoğan stated that the contents of the lorries were a national secret, but later claimed that they had been carrying humanitarian aid to the [[Syrian Turkmen|Turkmen population in Syria]]. He branded the prosecutor and gendarmerie troops involved in the search of the lorries as parallel structure sympathisers and many were subsequently arrested.{{cite web|url=http://siyasihaber.org/akpliler-mit-tirlarindaki-silahlar-icin-ne-demisti#.VWf4-IHJd2Y.twitter|title=AKP’liler Mit tırlarındaki silahlar için ne demişti?|work=Siyasi Haber}} ==Government reforms== ===Police and Judiciary=== Within 35 days of the 17 December anti-corruption operations, 5,000 police officers had been designated to positions elsewhere in the Directorate of Security.{{cite web|url=http://www.haberturk.com/gundem/haber/914998-35-gunde-5-bin-polis|title=35 günde 5 bin polis!|date=23 January 2014|work=www.haberturk.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sozcu.com.tr/2014/gundem/iste-emniyetteki-depremin-bilancosu-446344/|title=İşte Emniyet’teki depremin bilançosu!|date=23 January 2014|work=sozcu.com.tr}} Interior Minister [[Efkan Ala]] made a live statement claiming that 1,000 officers had been moved to new positions and 5,000 officers had been moved in a routine procedure. He claimed that this was a small percentage of re-designations compared to the total workforce of 260,000 officers.{{cite web|url=http://www.polishaber.net/efkan_ala_emniyette_gorevden_alma_olmadi-12079h.htm|title=Efkan Ala: Emniyette görevden alma olmadı|author=Polis Haber|date=22 February 2014|work=polishaber.net}} As changes to the HSYK were being debated in Parliament, several members of the HSYK that openly criticised the new legislation were removed from their posts.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25578084.asp|title=HSYK kendini değiştirdi|author=Oya ARMUTÇU/ ANKARA|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}}{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/yazarlar/omer_sahin/hsykda_1_nolu_operasyon-1171044|title=HSYK'da 1 No'lu operasyon|author=ÖMERŞAHİN|work=Radikal}} In the [[Istanbul Çağlayan Justice Palace]], there was an overhaul of staff, with 90 out of 192 prosecutors being reassigned from their original positions. Prosecutors dealing with the [[Sledgehammer (coup plan)|sledgehammer]] and [[Ergenekon trials]] were also involved in the mass overhaul. The prosecutors dealing with the 17 December operations were removed from their positions entirely.{{cite web|url=http://www.haberturk.com/gundem/haber/916860-caglayan-adliyesinde-deprem|title=Çağlayan Adliyesi'nde deprem|date=29 January 2014|work=www.haberturk.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25693718.asp|title=Adliyede köklü değişiklik|author=Fırat ALKAÇ/İSTANBUL|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} Erdoğan later made a speech alleging that the Gülen Movement had taken over the judiciary and claimed that they had made a mistake in pushing for constitutional changes in the [[Turkish constitutional referendum, 2010|2010 referendum]]. He further claimed that the HSYK had allowed phones to be wiretapped at will, which was why the government had put forward such significant reforms.{{cite web|url=http://www.takvim.com.tr/Guncel/2014/03/06/basbakandan-yargida-reform-sinyali|title=Başbakan'dan yargıda reform sinyali!|work=takvim.com.tr}} The government also abolished courts with special privileges ''(özel yetkili mahkemeler, ÖYM)'' as part of a democratisation package. ===2014 MİT reform law=== Besides tightening control over the judiciary, the government brought forward a new law that gave significant new powers to the [[National Intelligence Organization (Turkey)|National Intelligence Organisation]] (MİT). The new law would give the Council of Ministers the right to assign duties to MİT operatives on issues of counter-terrorism, national or external security. The term 'national security' raised the most concern due to its vagueness, meaning that a minister could potentially assign the MİT to conduct an operation against any political party, group, organisation or institution simply by claiming that they were a national security threat. The new law also gave the MİT the power to confiscate or demand access to any form of information, material or equipment contained by an organisation by overriding any other laws protecting privacy. Furthermore, leaking MİT documents was made a new crime, with long jail terms imposed on individuals who disclose information on the MİT's activities. The MİT was also given the right to conduct unlimited surveillance and a legal ground was instituted for talks between the MİT and imprisoned [[PKK]] leader [[Abdullah Öcalan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/security/2014/02/turkey-draft-law-intelligence-sweeping-powers.html#|title=Draft law would drastically expand Turkish MIT's powers - Al-Monitor: the Pulse of the Middle East|work=Al-Monitor}} ===2014 Internet censorship law=== The government passed a new controversial internet censorship law in 2014 that gave the [[Presidency of Telecommunication and Communication]] (TİB) to block websites without court authorisation should they reveal private or 'insulting' content. The law also made censorship much easier while also forcing websites to keep data of their users for a prolonged period of time and to disclose such information should the TİB require it. The new law was described as an open attack on social media due to the strengthening of existing [[censorship in Turkey|censorship laws]], with the lack of checks and balances on the TİB's decisions also being criticised.{{cite web|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/2/6/turkish-parliamentadoptsinternetcensorshipbill.html|title=Turkish parliament adopts Internet censorship bill|work=aljazeera.com}} Social media had a significant impact on the [[Gezi Park protests]] and the organisation of other anti-government demonstrations. A week before the [[Turkish local elections, 2014|2014 local elections]], ''[[Twitter]]'' and ''[[YouTube]]'' were blocked using the new powers given to the TİB.{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}} ===Release of Ergenekon and Balyoz prisoners=== The [[Sledgehammer (coup plan)|Sledgehammer]] and [[Ergenekon trials|Ergenekon]] cases were brought forward, allegedly as a joint effort between the AKP and Gulen Movement, in 2007 against critics of the AKP that threatened the party's hold on power. Such individuals included several military officers and journalists, including former Chief of General Staff [[Çetin Doğan]]. The cases were both riddled with claims of irregularities, though many defendants were either sentenced to life in prison for attempting a coup or charged while in jail.{{Citation needed|date=August 2016}} In February 2014, a law limited the time in which an accused could be imprisoned while formally charged to five years, meaning several Sledgehammer or Ergenekon defendants were released.{{cite web|url=http://www.milliyet.com.tr|title=MİLLİYET HABER - TÜRKİYE'NİN HABER SİTESİ|work=milliyet.com.tr}} An Istanbul court ordered the release of 230 people after ruling that their rights had been breached.http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/6a1d00e2-f7d1-11e3-baf5-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3dvRW9C6A In 2015, Erdoğan claimed that the entire country had been misled and deceived during the Sledgehammer case.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnnturk.com/haber/turkiye/erdogan-subaylara-seslendi-aldatildik|title=Erdoğan subaylara seslendi: ''Aldatıldık''|date=20 March 2015|work=CNN Türk}} ==Tape recording revelations== On the evening of 25 February 2014, a recording was posted on YouTube allegedly featuring Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] telling his son Necmettin Bilal Erdoğan to 'nullify' all the cash kept in their home due to the ongoing operations occurring in other government ministers' homes. The Prime Minister called the tape a 'dastardly, shameless and nasty montage', adding that there was nothing that he could not give a justification to. He claimed that the perpetrators behind the montage were members of the parallel structure (i.e. the Gulen Movement) and committed to beginning legal proceedings into the recording, as well as proving that it was a forgery. The recording was broadcast in Parliament by opposition leader [[Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu]], who claimed that new revelations would emerge in the following days and called for the Prime Minister to 'grab a helicopter and flee the country or resign'. Legal proceedings began into Kılıçdaroğlu for broadcasting the recording to Parliament, with him being accused of acquiring the recording through illegal methods. Despite the investigation later being abandoned, the court decided to restart the case in June 2015. The MHP leader [[Devlet Bahçeli]] claimed that the tapes put minds into shock, adding that the unjustifiable recording would go down in Turkish history as a disgrace. ===Investigations into possible forgery=== Despite claiming that the recordings were forged and vowing to bring forward evidence to prove this to be true, the government failed to bring forward proof in the first few days after a recording. The pro-government newspaper ''Star'' claimed that the government had received a report from an American company (John Marshall Media) confirming the recording to be a fake. However, the company CEO later took to Facebook stating that they did deal with legal verifications of tape recordings and stated that the report bearing their company name was a fake, announcing that they would look into possible legal action into their brand name being used unlawfully.{{cite web|url=http://t24.com.tr/haber/amerikali-sirket-montaj-raporunu-yalanladi-bu-sahtekarliktan-utanin,252124|title='Amerikalı şirket montaj raporunu yalanladı: Bu sahtekarlıktan utanın!'|work=t24.com.tr}} The main institution the government turned to for a report confirming the forgery was the [[Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey]] (TÜBİTAK), which examined the recording but failed to produce any proof that it was a fake. As a result, six TÜBİTAK experts at were fired in late February, with Minister [[Fikri Işık]] accusing them of supporting Gülen and accusing the parallel structure in general of infiltrating TÜBİTAK.{{cite web|url=http://www.bianet.org/bianet/toplum/153762-tubitak-ta-6-kisi-gorevden-alindi|title=TÜBİTAK'ta 6 Kişi Görevden Alındı|work=Bianet - Bagimsiz Iletisim Agi}}{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/ses_kaydinin_faturasi_tubitaka_cikti-1178686|title=Ses kaydının faturası TÜBİTAK'a çıktı|date=26 February 2014|work=Radikal}} In June 2014, TÜBİTAK eventually produced a report confirming the recordings to be a fake, though the report was found to be unconvincing and 'funny' by some vocal experts.{{cite web|url=http://www.sozcu.com.tr/2014/gundem/tubitakin-montaj-raporu-komik-527316/|title=TÜBİTAK’ın ‘montaj’ raporu komik|date=8 June 2014|work=sozcu.com.tr}} The CHP claimed that the technology that TÜBİTAK had used (syllable analysis) to produce their report did not actually exist, taking the issue to Parliament.{{cite web|url=http://www.bugun.com.tr/gundem/bunlar-da-mi-montaj-haberi/1137605|title=CHP TÜBİTAK'ın 'montaj' kararını Meclis'e taşıdı|work=Bugun.com.tr}} ===Wiretapping claims=== Energy and Natural Resources Minister [[Taner Yıldız]] claimed that the recording had been made for an Islamist organisation called 'Selam'.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25879315.asp|title='Selam' örgütü iddiası gündemi sarstı|author=İSTANBUL|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} Pro government newspapers ''[[Sabah]]'', ''Star'' and ''[[Yeni Şafak]]'' accused the parallel structure of wiretapping 20,000, 2,280 and 7,000 people respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/star/2014-02-26|title=Star Gazetesi - 26 Şubat 2014|work=gazete5.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/yeni-safak/2014-02-25|title=Yeni Şafak Gazetesi - 25 Şubat 2014|work=gazete5.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/sabah/2014-02-25|title=Sabah Gazetesi - 25 Şubat 2014|work=gazete5.com}} Their estimates widely increased in the following days, with ''Yeni Şafak'' claiming that the true number was above 100,000. The [[Presidency of Telecommunication and Communication]] (TİB) stated in March that 509,000 phones had been wiretapped between 2012 and 2013, though the TİB only had court warrants to wiretap 217,863 phones.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/25959220.asp|title=TİB: 2012 ve 2013'de 509 bin kişi dinlendi|author=AA|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} The former Vice President of TÜBİTAK, Hasan Palaz, and two other former TÜBİTAK workers were arrested for alleged wiretapping of the Prime Ministry, though Palaz was later released.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com.tr/haber/hasan-palaz-tutuklandi|title=Hasan Palaz tutuklandı|work=Al Jazeera Turk - Ortadoğu, Kafkasya, Balkanlar, Türkiye ve çevresindeki bölgeden son dakika haberleri ve analizler}} The Vice President of the TİB Osman Nihat Şen was also arrested.{{cite web|url=http://t24.com.tr/haber/yasa-disi-dinleme-sorusturmasinda-7-kisi-serbest-birakildi-4-kisi-tutuklandi,284596|title=Yasa dışı dinleme soruşturmasında 7 kişi serbest bırakıldı, 4 kişi tutuklandı|work=t24.com.tr}} A total of 26 people were arrested on charges of wiretapping and spying, including five police officers.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/turkce/haberler/2015/01/150122_casusluk_kriptolu_dinleme_tutuklama|title=Kriptolu telefon dinleme iddiasına 4 tutuklama|work=BBC Türkçe}} ==2014 local elections== {{main article|Turkish local elections, 2014}} The local elections on 30 March 2014 was the first election since the conflict began, with the AKP facing a serious test of confidence following the corruption charges. With 42.87% of the vote, the AKP won the elections with a significant proportion of councillors and mayors up for election. The CHP, hoping for a large boost in their vote share after running a fierce anti-corruption campaign, won just 26.34% of the vote (only 0.36% up from their [[Turkish general election, 2011|2011 election result]]). Many opposition members alleged widespread electoral fraud, especially in [[Ankara]] and [[Antalya]], with electricity cuts and provocations during vote counting causing heavy controversy.{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2014/03/30/erdogans_akp_wins_most_of_turkeys_mayoral_elections.html|title=Erdogan’s AKP wins most of Turkey’s mayoral elections|publisher=Toronto amid fraud claims|publisher=Hurriyet Daily News|date=30 March 2014|accessdate=31 March 2014}}{{cite İşte CHP oylarının çalındığının belgeleri|work=gazetecileronline.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006072457/http://www.gazetecileronline.com/newsdetails/13294-/GazetecilerOnline/secimler-hileli-iste-chp-oylarinin-calindiginin-be|archivedate=6 October 2014|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.haber7.com/yerel-yonetimler/haber/1142628-toprakkalede-oylar-yakildi|title=Toprakkale'de oylar yakıldı!|date=30 September 2014|work=Haber7}}http://www.enerjihaber.com/komur_talebi_patladi-3-haber-2091.html{{cite web|url=http://www.sabah.com.tr/Gundem/2014/03/29/oy-kullanamayacaklar-cunku-olu-gorunuyorlar|title=Oy kullanamayacaklar, çünkü 'ölü' görünüyorlar|date=29 March 2014|work=Sabah}} In a balcony speech declaring the AKP's victory, Erdoğan claimed that the population had given him a mandate to continue his fight against the parallel structure.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/26119975.asp|title=30 Mart balkon konuşması|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}} He further stated that the parallel structure's treachery would not be forgotten and that he had been a victim of his own good intentions, which was a perceived reference to the AKP's traditionally cosy relationship with Gulen.{{cite web|url=http://www.bugun.com.tr/son-dakika/erdogan-millet-bize-paralel-yapi--haberi/1052247|title=Erdoğan: Millet bize paralel yapı ile mücadele talimatı verdi|work=Bugun.com.tr}} Finally, Erdoğan pledged to have Gulen's sympathisers tried before the people and not the courts that they had 'infiltrated'.{{cite web|url=http://www.cumhuriyet.com.tr/haber/siyaset/58569/Erdogan__Halk__paralel_yapiyla_mucadele_yetkisi_verdi.html|title=Cumhuriyet Gazetesi - Erdoğan: Halk, paralel yapıyla mücadele yetkisi verdi|date=8 April 2014|work=cumhuriyet.com.tr}} ==Accusations of armed terrorism== With numerous prosecutors, soldiers, police officers and journalists known to be close to the Gulen Movement being arrested on charges of 'setting up an armed terrorist group', accusations of terrorism against the Movement have increased. A retired judge and a defendant during the [[Sledgehammer (coup plan)|Sledgehammer]] case, Ahmet Zeki Üçok claimed that the parallel structure had formed a terrorist cell named 'Ötüken'. It was claimed alleged that the cell had played a part in the [[assassination of Hrant Dink]], the [[Zirve Publishing House massacre]], the [[Turkish Council of State shooting]] and [[civil unrest]] in the [[Gezi Park protests]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gazete5.com/gazete-mansetleri/aksam/2014-04-14|title=Akşam Gazetesi - 14 Nisan 2014|work=gazete5.com}} A journalist from ''[[Akşam]]'', the newspaper in which the allegations had been made, resigned.{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/turkiye/aksam_gazetesinden_otuken_istifasi-1186537|title=Akşam gazetesinde 'Ötüken' istifası|date=14 April 2014|work=Radikal}} ==Controversies== The conflict has caused widespread controversy both politically and internationally, mainly revolving around Erdoğan's political polarising response and the uncertainty of the future of Turkish judicial independence. ===Domestic opposition=== The [[Republican People's Party (Turkey)|Republican People's Party]] (CHP), which forms the main opposition, was heavily critical of the government for their reforms to the judiciary and the [[2013 corruption scandal in Turkey|corruption scandal]]. It was perceived by some that the newspaper ''[[Zaman (newspaper)|Zaman]]'' had begun implicitly supporting the CHP in order to sustain the Gulen Movement's influence in politics and parliament. After opposition MPs began receiving letters from Gulen's supporters urging them to oppose the cram school law, the CHP took the law closing the schools to court.{{cite web|url=http://www.evrensel.net/haber/82519/chp-dershanelerin-kapatilmasini-aymye-goturdu|title=CHP, dershanelerin kapatılmasını AYM'ye götürdü|work=Evrensel.net}} After the 2013 corruption scandal, the CHP strongly condemned the government and called for Erdoğan's resignation, to which the Prime Minister responded by accusing CHP leader [[Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu]] of collaborating with Gulen. The CHP also accused the government of violating the independence of the judiciary with their reforms following the scandal. During the 2014 local election campaign, the CHP took a strong anti-corruption stance while the AKP accused the CHP of being pro-Gulen. The CHP's former spokesperson Birgül Ayman Güler resigned after accusing her party of allying itself with the Gulen Movement.{{cite web|url=http://www.radikal.com.tr/politika/chpde_cemaatle_ittifak_kavgasi_buyuyor-1253414|title=CHP'de 'cemaatle ittifak' kavgası büyüyor|date=17 December 2014|work=Radikal}} The CHP has also defended imprisoned ''Zaman'' journalists and have visited them in prison, while also coming out in support for [[Bank Asya]] during the government's attempt to shut it down.{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/gundem/28158058.asp|title=CHP'li vekillerden Hidayet Karaca ve Yakub Saygılı'ya ziyaret|author=Cem TURSUN / İSTANBUL, (DHA)|work=HÜRRİYET - TÜRKİYE'NİN AÇILIŞ SAYFASI}}{{cite web|url=http://odatv.com/n.php?n=kilicdaroglu-cemaatin-bankasina-sahip-cikti-1709141200|title=Kılıçdaroğlu Cemaat'in bankasına sahip çıktı|work=odatv.com}} These actions fuelled accusations that the CHP had now become the party of the Gulen Movement. Allegedly expecting many Gulen-supporting AKP voters to defect during the local elections, the CHP only won 26.34%, an increase of just 0.36% since the [[Turkish general election, 2011|2011 general election]]. However, the CHP has been historically heavily critical of the Gulen Movement, having been strongly against the judicial misconduct during the Sledgehammer and Ergenekon trials. Many Sledgehammer and Ergenekon defendants such as [[Mustafa Balbay]] are now CHP MPs, having been elected in an attempt to free them from prison. ===International concerns=== Concerns have been raised by the [[US Congress]], the [[European Union]] and several other human rights groups over the Turkish government's tightening control over the judiciary, as well as increased government censorship of social media. In January 2014, the EU issued a call for Turkey to preserve press freedom and judicial independence, criticising the large-scale reorganisation of judges and the censorship of social media networks.{{cite web|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/_keep-your-courts-independent-eu-to-tell-turkey_360986.html|title=Keep your courts independent, EU to tell Turkey|date=8 October 2014|work=TodaysZaman}} In January 2015, the EU Enlargement Commissioner [[Štefan Füle]] called on [[Ankara]] to restore judicial independence in order to make progress in its [[Accession of Turkey to the European Union|accession negotiations]].{{cite web|url=http://www.euractiv.com/video/eu-urges-turkey-restore-judiciary-independence-307652|title=EU urges Turkey to restore judiciary independence|work=EurActiv - EU News & policy debates, across languages}} The [[United States Congress]] has urged Secretary of State [[John Kerry]] to push Turkey for a free press after the raids on pro-Gulen newspapers that saw the arrest of Samanyolu TV director {{Interlanguage link multi|Hidayet Karaca|tr}} and ''Zaman'' editor-in-chief [[Ekrem Dumanlı]].{{cite web|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/anasayfa_dozens-of-us-congress-members-urge-kerry-to-press-turkey-for-freer-media_371845.html|title=Dozens of US Congress members urge Kerry to press Turkey for freer media|date=5 February 2015|work=TodaysZaman}} Following the police raids on pro-Gulen media, the US Congress condemned Turkey for an "assault on democracy".{{cite web|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/anasayfa_us-congressional-caucus-condemns-turkey-media-crackdown-as-assault-on-democracy_367515.html|title=US Congressional caucus condemns Turkey media crackdown as ’assault on democracy’|date=19 December 2014|work=TodaysZaman}} ==Purge of the Gulenist movement in Turkey== {{see also|2016–17 purges in Turkey|2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt}} In 2016 a faction within the military loyal not to the state, but to Fethullah Gülen, [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt|allegedly tried to overthrow the Turkish government]]. 249 Turks were killed resisting the coup. In rebuttal of these attempted-coup allegations, the London-based Hizmet Centre, a Gulen-movement source, said that Gulen had remarked within a speech broadcast August 13, 2017 "about a rumour of a plot, that some important public figures will be assassinated in Turkey, and the blame will be put on the members of the Hizmet [Gulen] movement. Gulen’s message...was allegedly distorted by pro-Erdogan and anti-Gulen media circles as 'an order of assassination to his followers'".https://www.neweurope.eu/article/hizmet-centre-takes-erdogan-regime/ Turkey’s Justice Ministry said on July 13 that 50,510 people have been arrested and 169,013 have been charged with complicity with the coup attempt. Many of those arrested or charged and are associated with the Gulen movement.https://turkeypurge.com/govt-says-616-gulen-followers-were-detained-in-past-week The government has charged people merely associated with the Gulen movement through such means as possession of an account with [[Bank Asya]], a Gulen-movement affiliated bank, or subscribing to ''[[Zaman (newspaper)|Zaman]]'', a Gulen-movement affiliated newspaper.https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/13/magazine/inside-turkeys-purge.html ==See also== *[[Samanyolu TV]] *''[[Zaman (newspaper)|Zaman]]'' *[[Turkish presidential election, 2014]] *[[2013 corruption scandal in Turkey]] *[[Censorship in Turkey]] *[[Parallel state]] *[[Gülen movement]] *[[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] *[[2016–17 purges in Turkey]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Turkish government - Gulen Movement conflict}} [[Category:2010s conflicts]] [[Category:2010s in Turkey]] [[Category:2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt]] [[Category:Conflicts in Turkey]] [[Category:Government of Turkey]] [[Category:Gülen movement]] [[Category:Religious persecution]] [[pt:Movimento Gülen#Perseguição]]

{{mergefrom|Bath ḳōl|discuss=Talk:Voice of God#Merger proposal|date=September 2017}} {{distinguish|Voice of the Gods}} {{redirect|Vox dei|other uses|Vox Dei (disambiguation)}} [[File:Ezekiel 1.jpeg|thumb|[[Ezekiel]] hears the voice, represented by the [[Hand of God (art)|Hand of God]], [[Dura-Europos Synagogue]], 3rd century CE.]] In Judaism and Christianity, the '''voice of God''' ({{lang-he|בּת קול}}, ''bat kol'' or ''bat ḳōl'', literally "daughter of voice"; [[Latin]]: ''vox dei'') is a "heavenly or divine voice which proclaims God's will or judgment."<ref name="JE">The [[Jewish Encyclopedia]]</ref> It is "identified with the Holy Spirit, even with God; but it differed essentially from the [[Prophet]]s, though these spoke as the medium of the [[Holy Spirit]]."<ref name=JE />
== Revelation == The characteristic attributes of the voice of God are the invisibility of the speaker and a certain remarkable quality in the sound, regardless of its strength or weakness. A sound proceeding from some invisible source was considered a heavenly voice, since the [[revelation]] on [[Biblical Mount Sinai|Sinai]] was given in that way in Deuteronomy 4:12: "Ye heard the voice of the words, but saw no similitude; only ye heard a voice". In this account, God reveals himself to man through his organs of hearing, not through those of sight. Even the prophet [[Ezekiel]], who sees many visions, "heard a voice of one that spake" (Ezek 1:28); similarly, [[Elijah]] recognized God by a "still, small voice," and a voice addressed him (I Kings 19:12–13; compare Job 4:16); sometimes God's voice rang from the heights, from Jerusalem, from Zion (Ezek. 1:25; Jer 25:30; Joel 3:16–17; Amos 1:2, etc.); and God's voice was heard in the thunder and in the roar of the sea.<ref name=JE />
The concept appears in {{bibleverse||Dan|4:31}}:<ref name="ISBE">The [[International Standard Bible Encyclopedia]]</ref>
:עוד מלתא בפם מלכא קל מן־ שׁמיא נפל לך אמרין נבוכדנצר מלכא מלכותה עדת מנך :[T]here fell a voice from heaven, saying, O king [[Nebuchadnezzar]], to thee it is spoken; The kingdom is departed from thee (emphasis added).
In Jewish art the ''Bat Ḳol'' was often represented by the [[Hand of God (art)|Hand of God]], as in the [[Synagogue of Dura-Europas]], which Christian art also adopted for the relevant New Testament scenes.
===In the New Testament=== In the [[New Testament]] mention of “a voice from [[heaven]]” occurs in the following passages: {{bibleverse||Matt|3:17}}; {{bibleverse||Mark|1:11}};<ref>And a voice came from heaven: "You are my Son, whom I love; with you I am well pleased."{{bibleverse|Mark|1:11|NIV}}</ref> {{bibleverse||Luke|3:22}} (at the [[baptism of Jesus]]); {{bibleverse||Matt|17:5}}; {{bibleverse||Mark|9:7}}; {{bibleverse||Luke|9:35}} (at the [[Transfiguration of Jesus|transfiguration]]); {{bibleverse|John|12:28}} (shortly before the [[Passion (Christianity)|Passion]]); {{bibleverse||Acts|9:4}}; {{bibleverse||Acts|22:7}}; {{bibleverse||Acts|26:14}} ([[conversion of Paul]]), and {{bibleverse||Acts|10:13}}, {{bibleverse||Acts|10:15}} (instruction of Peter concerning the [[Unclean animals|clean and unclean]]). In the period of the [[Tannaim]] (circa 100 BCE-200 CE) the term ''bath ḳōl'' was in very frequent use and was understood to signify not the direct voice of God, which was held to be supersensible, but the echo of the voice (the ''bath'' being somewhat arbitrarily taken to express the distinction). The rabbis held that ''bath ḳōl'' had been an occasional means of divine communication throughout the whole history of Israel and that since the cessation of the prophetic gift it was the sole means of Divine revelation. It is noteworthy that the rabbinical conception of ''bath ḳōl'' sprang up in the period of the decline of Old Testament [[prophecy]] and flourished in the period of extreme traditionalism. Where the gift of prophecy was believed to be lacking – perhaps even because of this lack – there grew up an inordinate desire for special divine manifestations. Often a voice from heaven was looked for to clear up matters of doubt and even to decide between conflicting interpretations of the law. So strong had this tendency become that Rabbi Joshua (''c''. 100 CE) felt it to be necessary to oppose it and to insist upon the supremacy and the sufficiency of the written law.
It is clear that we have here to do with a conception of the nature and means of divine revelation that is distinctly inferior to the Biblical view. For even in the Biblical passages where mention is made of the voice from heaven, all that is really essential to the revelation is already present, at least in principle, without the audible voice.<ref name=ISBE />
===Interpretation=== [[Josephus]] (Ant., XIII, x, 3) relates that [[John Hyrcanus]] (135–104 BCE) heard a voice while offering a [[burnt offering|burnt sacrifice]] in the [[Temple in Jerusalem|temple]], which Josephus expressly interprets as the voice of God.<ref name=ISBE />
Christian scholars interpreted Bath Kol as the Jews' replacement for the great prophets when, "after the death of Malachi, the spirit of prophecy wholly ceased in Israel" (taking the name to refer to its being "the daughter" of the main prophetic "voice").<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=r5c5yDLwnu8C&pg=PA215&lpg=PA215&dq=talmud+%22ben+lachish%22&source=web&ots=OPIvQpOje7&sig=_NRZpQbrqxKWJu5BQz1Fd_66RUU The Old and New Testament connected in the history of the Jews]</ref>
==In media== The generic term "voice of God" is commonly used in theatrical productions and staging, and refers to any anonymous, disembodied voice used to deliver general messages to the audience. Examples may include speaker introductions, audience directions and performer substitutions.
The origin of the "Voice of God" narration style was most probably in [[Time Inc]]'s "[[March of Time]]"<ref>Fielding, Raymond. The March of Time, 1935-1951. New York: Oxford University Press, 1978</ref> news-radio and news-film series, for which Orson Welles was an occasional voice-over actor, and was subsequently duplicated in [[Orson Welles|Welles]]' "[[Citizen Kane]]"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://xroads.virginia.edu/~ma04/wood/mot/html/kane.htm|title=Citizen Kane and other imitators|publisher=University of Virginia|author=Mary Wood|accessdate=2010-02-27}}</ref> ''News On The March'' sequence (the first reel of the film), much to the delight of [[Henry R. Luce]], Time's president.
